{{multiple issues|{{BLP sources|date=May 2013}} {{update|Aftermath|date=May 2016}}}} '''Jean-Claude Romand''' (born 11 February 1954) is a [[France|French]] [[murder]]er and [[impostor]] who pretended to be a medical doctor for 18 years before killing his wife, children, and his parents when he was about to be exposed.
== Early life ==
Jean-Claude Romand was born in [[Lons-le-Saunier]] and grew up in the village [[Clairvaux-les-Lacs]] in the ''[[Departments of France|département]]'' of [[Jura (department)|Jura]]. He studied at the ''[[lycée]]'' of Lons-le-Saunier until his ''[[baccalauréat]]''. In 1971, he registered at the ''[[Classe Préparatoire aux Grandes Écoles|classes préparatoires]]'' of [[Lycée du Parc]] in [[Lyon]], but dropped out after one term. Afterwards he enrolled as a medical student.
== Deception == The deception began with a simple lie: Romand claimed that he had passed a second-year medical examination that he did not take. He therefore never qualified as a doctor, a fact unknown to his parents.
Romand fooled his family and friends for 18 years; they thought he was a successful medical professional and researcher in the [[World Health Organization]] (WHO). He managed to give an impression that he had researched [[arteriosclerosis]] and that he had contacts with political figures.
In reality, he spent his days wandering and used the free information services of the local WHO building. He lived close by in [[Prévessin-Moëns]], France. Periodically he left for a supposed work trip but only traveled to [[Geneva International Airport]] and spent a couple of days in a hotel room there, studying medical journals and a travel guide about the various countries he lied about visiting. Romand lived off the money his wife and he had made by selling an apartment, from his wife's salary, and from sums of money which were given to him by various relatives, who relied on his assurances that he was investing the money in various imaginary [[hedge fund]]s and foreign ventures.<ref>''Le Roman d'un menteur'', [[France 2]] documentary, 1999</ref>
== Actions on the night of the murders == {{BLP unsourced section|date=April 2018}} On 9 January 1993 Romand withdrew 2000 francs and borrowed a .22 Long Rifle carbine from his father for which he purchased a [[suppressor]], and gas canisters, and asked for them to be gift wrapped. That night, he beat his wife to death on the couple's double bed with a rolling pin. He left her body until the morning, sleeping as normal. The next morning, he woke his children, had breakfast, and watched cartoons. He put them to bed that night, and once they had fallen asleep, shot them both in the head. After these killings, the only people who could expose him were his parents and his ex-mistress, who wanted back 900,000 francs that she had given him as a favour.
The next morning, Romand travelled to his parents' house, where he joined them for a meal. Immediately after the meal he repeatedly shot them both and the family dog.
That night he picked up his ex-mistress, telling her they were invited to a dinner with the then health minister, Bernard Kouchner. Pretending that they were lost, he made her exit the car, and as she did so he attempted to strangle her with a cord and sprayed [[tear gas]] into her face. After she fought back, he apologized and drove her back to her home, after making her promise to never tell anyone about his attempt to murder her. He then returned to his family home, which still contained the bodies of his dead wife and children.
He sat and watched television before he poured [[petrol]] around the house, set it on fire, and took an overdose of sleeping pills to create the appearance of an intended suicide. Whether this attempt was genuine is doubtful, since the pills he took were long expired, and he had access to more effective [[barbiturate]]s; additionally, the manner in which the fire was set and the timing of his taking the pills made his rescue inevitable.<ref name="ReferenceA">''L'Adversaire (The Adversary)'', [[Emmanuel Carrère]] book, 2000</ref> He was rescued by local firefighters who were alerted by the road cleaners at 4:00 the next morning.
He survived the blaze, but refused to talk to police during subsequent questioning; it was initially believed that he was too traumatized to speak.
==Aftermath== Romand's trial began on 25 June 1996. On 6 July 1996 Romand was sentenced to [[life imprisonment]] with no possibility of parole for 22 years; he has been eligible for parole since 2015.<ref name="ReferenceA"/> Romand is reputed to suffer from [[narcissistic personality disorder]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.enhancetv.com.au/shop/product.php?productid=103474&cat=330&page=12|title=Warning :: EnhanceTV|publisher=}}</ref>
== Documentary and fiction == {{BLP unsourced section|date=April 2018}} French author [[Emmanuel Carrère]] entered into correspondence with imprisoned Romand to write a book, published in 2000, ''L'Adversaire'' (''[[The Adversary (Carrère book)|The Adversary]]''), based on the case. [[Nicole Garcia]] directed a movie, ''[[L'Adversaire]]'' (2002), based on the book; actor [[Daniel Auteuil]] played the part of Romand (renamed Jean-Marc Faure in the film). Two other movies were loosely based on Romand's life: the French ''[[L'Emploi du temps]]'' (2001) (English title: ''Time Out'') and the Spanish ''{{Interlanguage link multi|La vida de nadie|es}}'' (English title: ''Nobody's Life''). Romand's deception also formed the basis of the "Subterraneans" episode of the [[BBC]] crime drama [[Waking the Dead (TV series)|''Waking The Dead'']] (third episode of the fifth season in 2005). The episode 16 (season 1) [[Phantom (Law & Order: Criminal Intent episode)|"Phantom"]] of ''[[Law & Order: Criminal Intent]]'' is also constructed around this story.
== Footnotes == {{reflist}}
==References== * ''The Man Who Faked His Life'', Channel 4 Documentary, 2005, director and producer [[Liz Tucker]] [http://www.channel4.com/health/microsites/P/psycho/man.html]
{{Authority control}}

page.title: List of air show accidents and incidents in the 21st century

revision.text:
{{Use mdy dates|date=July 2018}} [[File:F16 Idaho airshow.jpg|thumb|200px|F-16 Ejection at Mountain Home, Idaho September 15, 2003]] {{Dynamic a-list}}
This is a year-by-year '''list of aviation accidents''' that have occurred at '''[[air show|airshows]]''' worldwide in the 21st century. __NOTOC__
<!--begin compact toc--> {| |- ! style="background:#ddd; text-align:center;" colspan="10"| List of airshow accidents in the 21st century |- style="background:#ddd;" || [[#2011|2011]] || [[#2012|2012]] || [[#2013|2013]] || [[#2014|2014]] || [[#2015|2015]] || [[#2016|2016]] || [[#2017|2017]] || 2018 || [[#2019| ]] || [[#2020| ]] |- style="background:#ddd;" || [[#2001|2001]] || [[#2002|2002]] || [[#2003|2003]] || [[#2004|2004]] || [[#2005|2005]] || [[#2006|2006]] || [[#2007|2007]] || [[#2008|2008]] || [[#2009|2009]] || [[#2010|2010]] |- | style="background:#ddd; text-align:center;" colspan="10"| [[#See also|See also]] – [[#References|References]] – [[#External links|External links]] |} <!--end compact toc-->
== 2018 == *October 12 - Jon Thocker, a member of the Redline Airshows Aerobatic Team, was killed when his [[Van's Aircraft RV-8|Van's RV-8]] crashed while performing a nighttime aerobatic routine at Culpeper Airfest in [[Culpeper, VA]]. This was the second fatal airshow accident to occur at Culpeper Airfest in over a decade (the first being [[Nancy Lynn]]; see 2006 below). *July 7 – A MiG-21 Lancer crashed at the Borcea Air Base in Southern Romania. The pilot, Florin Rotaru, was killed. *June 2 – Dan Buchanan, a hang glider pilot, was killed during the Gunfighter Skies Air and Space Celebration at Mountain Home Air Force Base.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.newsairshow.com/headlines/2018/6/2/dan-buchanan-passes-away-following-incident-at-mountain-home-afb |website=Airshow News |accessdate=28 August 2018 |title=DAN BUCHANAN PASSES AWAY FOLLOWING INCIDENT AT MOUNTAIN HOME AFB}}</ref> *May 30 – Ken Johansen, a member of the GEICO Skytypers team, was killed when his SNJ-2 aircraft crashed in Melville, NY on Long Island. *April 26 - Eglin Wells, an aerobatic pilot from Atlanta, GA, was killed when his custom-designed and -built Starjammer aircraft crashed while practicing for the Zhengzhou Air Show.<ref>http://airshowstuff.com/v4/2018/u-s-pilot-elgin-wells-killed-while-practicing-for-chinese-airshow/</ref>
== 2017 == *September 24 – Capt. Gabriele Orlandi of the Italian Air Force died while performing at an air show in [[Terracina]]. The pilot was not able to recover from a loop and his plane, a [[Eurofighter Typhoon]], crashed into the sea.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://abcnews.go.com/International/wireStory/italy-air-force-eurofighter-crashes-air-show-pilot-50061571|title=Italy air force Eurofighter crashes at air show, pilot dead|last=News|first=ABC|publisher=ABC News|access-date=25 September 2017}}</ref> *July 16 – Vlado Lenoch and passenger Bethany Root were killed when their [[P-51D Mustang]] "Baby Duck" crashed in a field in Cummings, Kansas after performing at the Amelia Earhart Festival. *May 28 – [[Petty officer, first class]] Remington Peters, a member of the United States Navy Parachute Team "[[Leap Frogs]]" died when his parachute malfunctioned and did not open while he was performing at [[Fleet Week|Fleet Week New York City]].<ref>[http://abc7ny.com/news/at-least-1-parachutist-seriously-hurt-in-accident-at-fleet-week-event-/2047521/ U.S. Navy SEAL Killed in Parachute Accident at Fleet Week Event in Jersey City]</ref> *May 14 – Chris Burkett, a member of the Twister Aerobatics Team, who was piloting the [[Silence Twister|Silence SA1100 Twister]] at the time had to make an emergency landing while participating in the [[Abingdon Air & Country Show]] in [[Abingdon, Oxfordshire]], United Kingdom. The aircraft is in need of repairs and the pilot suffered minor injuries.<ref>[http://www.dailystar.co.uk/news/latest-news/614131/pilot-plane-nosedive-ground-crash-hospital-emergency-Abingdon-Air-Country-Show-Oxfordshire UPDATE: Footage released of air show DISASTER as plane nosedives to ground].</ref> *January 28 – A pilot was forced to make a wheels up landing in the Chance-Vought F4U-5N Corsair he was flying due to a failure of its hydraulic system. The incident happened at the Hunter Valley Airshow in [[Rutherford, New South Wales]], Australia.<ref>[http://www.worldwarbirdnews.com/2017/01/28/video-f4u-corsair-makes-wheels-up-landing-at-hunter-valley-airshow-in-australia/ Video: F4U Corsair Makes Wheels-Up Landing at Hunter Valley Airshow in Australia].</ref> *January 26 – [[Australia Day]] celebrations (Perth, Australia) – A [[Grumman G-73 Mallard]] flying boat (VH-CQA), crashed into the [[Swan River (Western Australia)|Swan River]] in [[Perth]], Australia during [[Australia Day]] celebrations. The pilot Peter Lynch and passenger Endah Cakrawati died on impact. [https://aviation-safety.net/database/record.php?id=20170126-0] *January 14 – Hat Yai Airshow during Children Day ([[Hat Yai]], [[Thailand]]) – Pilot Dilokrit Pattavee died when his [[Saab JAS 39 Gripen]] number 70108 crashed at the Hat Yai Airshow in [[Hat Yai]], Thailand.<ref>[http://www.bangkokpost.com/news/general/1180041/gripen-jet-crashes-during-air-show-pilot-killed Gripen Jet Crashes during Air Show – Pilot Killed]</ref>
== 2016 == *August 27 – Alaska-native pilot Marcus Paine was killed when his 450 Stearman biplane crashed during the Airshow of the Cascades in Madras, Oregon.{{citation needed|date=June 2017}} *August 14 – [[Herne Bay, Kent]] – A pilot suffered minor injuries when his plane crashed and flipped over near the shore during an airshow.<ref>{{cite news|title=Plane crashes into sea at air show|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/av/uk-37081840/plane-crashes-into-sea-at-air-show|accessdate=June 18, 2017|work=''BBC News''|date=August 15, 2016}}</ref> *July 22 – Aerobatic pilot Randy Harris and passenger Dale Shillington were killed when their Skybolt Biplane lost control and crashed in a field near Vance AFB in Oklahoma.{{citation needed|date=June 2017}} *July 17 – A [[North American T-28 Trojan|T-28]] crashed at The Cold Lake Air Show in Alberta, Canada, killing the pilot, Bruce Evans, upon impact with the ground.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://globalnews.ca/news/2830228/alberta-air-show-cancelled-after-plane-crash/?sf31146704=1|title=‘He just nosedived straight down’: witness to deadly plane crash at Alberta air show|first=Phil|last=Heidenreich}}</ref> *July 13 – Mesmer Family Block Party ([[Grand Island, New York]]) – Skydiver Jeffrey Antonich was seriously injured when he experienced a hard landing while performing during a privately held airshow in front of an estimated 1,000 spectators.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Reilly|first1=Ed|title=Skydiver critical after air show accident|url=http://www.wkbw.com/news/skydiver-taken-to-ecmc-after-air-show-accident|accessdate=June 18, 2017|publisher=WKBW.com|date=July 13, 2016}}</ref> *June 5 – A [[de Havilland Tiger Moth]] crashed at [[Brimpton Airfield]] near Reading, England injuring a spectator at a fly-in to raise funds for the local air ambulance.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/home-news/spectator-taken-to-hospital-after-tiger-moth-biplane-crashes-near-reading-brimpton-airfield-a7066646.html|title=Spectator taken to hospital after Tiger Moth biplane crashes|date=June 5, 2016}}</ref> *May 28 – Pilot Bill Gordon died when his P-47 Thunderbolt "Jacky's Revenge" crash landed in the Hudson River. *May 14 – Aerobatic pilot Greg Connell crashed and died during a performance at the Good Neighbor Day Air Show at [[DeKalb-Peachtree Airport]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.ajc.com/news/news/local/air-show-pilot-killed-at-dekalb-peachtree-airport/nrNCm/ |title=Parents asked to turn children away after fatal PDK air show crash |last1=Eldridge |first1=Ellen |date=May 15, 2016 |publisher=Atlanta Journal Constitution |accessdate=May 17, 2016}}</ref> *April 17 – Guatemalan pilot Juan Miguel García Salas died when his [[Extra EA-300]]L aerobatics plane crashed in a wooded area near Aeródromo Capitán Eduardo Toledo while performing at the Cozumel Aero Show in [[Cozumel]], [[Quintana Roo]], Mexico.<ref>{{cite web |title=ASN Wikibase Occurrence # 186515 |publisher=Flight Safety Foundation |date=April 17, 2016 |url=https://aviation-safety.net/wikibase/wiki.php?id=186515 |accessdate=April 18, 2016}}</ref>
== 2015 == *December 20 – Air Force Flight School ([[Yogyakarta|Yogyakarta, Indonesia]]) – Both pilots of a [[KAI T-50 Golden Eagle]] were killed when their aircraft crashed while performing during the 70th anniversary ceremonies of the flight school.<ref>{{cite news|title=Jet fighter crashes at Indonesian air show; 2 dead|url=http://www.seattletimes.com/nation-world/jet-fighter-crashes-at-indonesian-air-show-2-dead/|accessdate=June 18, 2017|work=The Seattle Times|agency=Associated Press|date=December 19, 2015}}</ref> *October 18 – Wings Over Houston Air Show (Harris County, Texas) – A skydiver was injured when he landed on a supply tent. It was reported that he did not hear the order cancelling the formation jump due to high winds.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Spencer|first1=Bill|title=Parachutist crashes into tent at Wings Over Houston Air Show|url=http://www.click2houston.com/news/parachutist-crashes-into-tent-at-wings-over-houston-air-show_2015112315524796|publisher=click2houston.com|date=October 19, 2015}}</ref> * September 12 – An [[Aero L-39 Albatros]] jet, piloted by Jay "Flash" Gordon of Louisville, Kentucky, crashed approximately two minutes after take-off at the Wings Over Big South Fork Air & Car Show in [[Scott County, Tennessee]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Pilot killed after crash during Scott Co. air show|url=http://www.wbir.com/story/news/local/scott-campbell-morgan/2015/09/12/plane-crash--wings-over--big-south-fork-air-and-car-show/72164642/|accessdate=September 19, 2015|publisher=WBIR-TV|date=September 14, 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Pilot confirmed dead in Scott Co. airshow crash|url=http://www.knoxnews.com/news/state/pilot-confirmed-dead-in-scott-co-airshow-crash_28483589|accessdate=September 19, 2015|work=[[Knoxville News Sentinel]]|date=September 13, 2015}}</ref> * August 23 – Two Comco [[Ikarus C42]], a two-seat, fixed [[tricycle gear]], [[general aviation]] [[microlight]] airplane, manufactured in Germany by [[Comco Ikarus]] belonging to the "Grasshoppers" aerobatics team collided in mid-air during a three-ship display at the Dittinger Flugtage airshow in [[Dittingen]], Switzerland. Grasshopper 1 and 2 were involved in the collision. Grasshopper 2 (D-MUHH) impacted a road and a house in the village of Dittingen. The aircraft disintegrated and burned. Grasshopper 1 (D-MSON) came down on the fence of a residence in the village of Dittingen. The aircraft sustained substantial damage. A photo from the scene shows a ballistic recovery parachute attached to the wreckage.<ref>{{cite web| title = Amazing pictures show aftermath of Swiss mid-air plane crash which saw one pilot killed but another parachute to safety| work = Daily Mail |date=August 23, 2014 |url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-3207746/Two-planes-collide-Swiss-airshow-one-crashing-ground.html | accessdate =August 9, 2015}}</ref> * August 22 – [[2015 Shoreham Airshow crash]] – A [[Hawker Hunter T7]] (G-BXFI/WV372) crashed onto the [[A27 road|A27]] arterial road (dual carriageway) between Lancing and Shoreham-by-Sea, West Sussex, England, while taking part in the 2015 [[Shoreham Airshow]]. Eleven people on the ground were killed and several others were injured, including the pilot of the plane. Witnesses told local TV that the jet appeared to have crashed when it failed to pull out of a loop maneuver.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-34034430|title=Shoreham air crash death toll 'rises to 11'|accessdate=August 23, 2015|date=August 23, 2015|work=BBC News}}</ref> * August 15 – Sgt. First Class Corey Hood, 32, a member of the [[United States Army Parachute Team|United States Army Parachute Team "Golden Knights"]] team died at [[Northwestern Memorial Hospital]] one day after he was critically injured when he struck an apartment building and fell to the ground following a mid-air collision with another parachutist belonging to the United States Navy Parachute Team "[[Leap Frogs]]" at the [[Chicago Air & Water Show]].<ref>{{cite news|last1=O'Connell|first1=Patrick M.|last2=Williams-Harris|first2=Deanese|last3=Rhodes|first3=Dawn|title=Army parachutist dies after Chicago Air & Water Show accident|url=http://www.chicagotribune.com/news/local/breaking/ct-chicago-air-water-parachutists-20150816-story.html|accessdate=September 19, 2015|work=Chicago Tribune|date=August 17, 2015}}</ref> * August 2 – One of the two pilots of a Mi-28N of the "berkuts" display team, died while performing in Ryazan Region (Russian) during "Aviadarts" air show. Their helicopter started spinning and crashed after a failure of the tail rotor. The other pilot managed to escape from the wreck with minor foot injuries.<ref>{{cite web| title = Russian Ministry of Defense: the preliminary cause of accident Mi-28N was an equipment failure| agency = Information Telegraph Agency of Russia| date =August 2, 2015 |url = http://tass.ru/proisshestviya/2159660 |accessdate =August 2, 2015}}</ref> video:<ref>{{cite web| title = Russia: Famous stunt pilot killed during aerobatic exercise| publisher = LiveLeak| date =August 2, 2015| url = http://www.liveleak.com/view?i=093_1438514288| accessdate =August 2, 2015}}</ref> * August 1 – [[CarFest#Air crash|CarFest]], Kevin Whyman died after his [[Folland Gnat]] crashed into the ground.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/uk-england-manchester-33748256|title=Pilot Kevin Whyman killed in CarFest crash in Cheshire|accessdate=December 11, 2015|date=August 1, 2015|work=BBC News}}</ref> * June 27 – Steven O’Berg died when his Pitts S2-B biplane spun into the ground at the Cameron Airshow.<ref>{{cite web| title =Smithville pilot dies from injuries in Cameron Airshow crash| publisher = Kansas City Star| date = June 28, 2015 |url =http://www.kansascity.com/news/local/article25724110.html| accessdate =August 24, 2015}}</ref> *June 27 - Minnesota Air Spectacular ([[Mankato, Minnesota]]) - Two people received slight injuries when a six-year old boy accidentally started a [[Eurocopter EC145]] medical transport helicopter that was on display at the airshow.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Walsh|first1=Paul|title=Young boy starts up Mayo helicopter at Mankato air show; 2 people hurt|url=http://www.startribune.com/boy-about-6-cranks-up-mayo-helicopter-at-mankato-air-show-2-people-nearby-hurt/310680611/|accessdate=June 18, 2017|work=Star Tribune|date=June 30, 2015}}</ref> * May 31 – Marco Ricci, member of the QBR team, died while performing in [[Alba Adriatica]]. After a mid-air collision with another member of the team, his plane plummeted to the sea. The pilot from the other plane survived thanks to a splashdown.<ref>{{cite web| title = Scontro tra due aerei a air show a Tortoreto in Abruzzo, muore un pilota. Mercoledì l'autopsia| publisher = Ansa| date = June 2, 2015 |url = http://www.ansa.it/abruzzo/notizie/2015/05/31/scontro-fra-2-aerei-pattuglia-acrobatica-in-abruzzo_f93f6206-8f96-4f9d-9a49-144e9d19d6ef.html| accessdate =August 2, 2015}}</ref> video:<ref>{{cite web| title = Aeroplanes Collide and Crash During Italian Airshow |publisher = LiveLeak| date =May 31, 2015 |url=http://www.liveleak.com/view?i=428_1433090414 |accessdate=August 2, 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=Airshow Plane Crash in Italy 5/31/2015 |publisher=LiveLeak |date=June 1, 2015 |url=http://www.liveleak.com/view?i=ed5_1433134045 |accessdate=August 2, 2015}}</ref> *February 19 – [[Aero India]] (Bangalore, India) – One plane of the Flying Bulls stunt team was damaged when two planes made contact mid-air while performing, both planes landed safely.<ref>{{cite news|title=Close call for stunt planes at India air show|url=http://www.cbsnews.com/news/india-air-show-stunt-planes-close-call/|accessdate=June 18, 2017|publisher=CBS News|agency=Associated Press|date=February 19, 2015}}</ref>
== 2014 == * September 21 – {{Interlanguage link multi|Francesco Fornabaio|it}} died at the age of 57 during the "Fly Venice 2014" at the [[Giovanni Nicelli Airport]] in Venice, Italy in his [[XtremeAir Sbach 300|Extreme 3000]].<ref>{{cite web| title = Aereo da acrobazie cade al Lido di Venezia, muore il campione mondiale Francesco Fornabaio| work = La Stampa |date=September 21, 2014 |url=http://www.lastampa.it/2014/09/21/italia/cronache/ultraleggero-precipita-al-lido-di-venezia-morto-il-pilota-dQJzJ8fS7mMhZz2aAvgARM/pagina.html| accessdate = August 2, 2015}}</ref> * July 31 – A [[Hawker Sea Fury]] performing the penultimate display at the [[Culdrose Air Day]] crash landed after an engine problem possibly due to lack of hydraulics. The crash was minor and the pilot survived.{{citation needed|date=September 2015}} * June 29 – Flying Circus Aerodrome, [[Bealeton, Virginia]] – While performing a routine act in the Flying Circus Airshow, a [[Waco UPF-7]] biplane experienced a total loss of power and was forced to make an emergency landing in an adjacent field. However, the landing roll was too fast for the pilot to safely stop the aircraft before it impacted a tree grove at the edge of the field, totally destroying the aircraft. The pilot managed to escape and walk away with minor injuries.{{citation needed|date=September 2015}} * June 29 – The Shuttleworth Collection's [[Sopwith Triplane]] hit a surrounding airfield fence on landing and ended up on its nose. The pilot Dodge Bailey escaped unhurt, but the aircraft suffered wing, undercarriage and propellor damage.{{citation needed|date=September 2015}} * June 1 – Bill Cowden died during the Stevens Point Airshow at the [[Stevens Point Municipal Airport]] in [[Stevens Point, Wisconsin]] in his [[Yakovlev Yak-55]]M.<ref>{{cite news|title=UPDATE: NTSB Reviewing Camera, GPS and Log Books from Plane Following Crash|url=http://www.wsaw.com/home/headlines/Plane-Crash-Reported-at-Stevens-Point-Airshow--261442161.html|accessdate=August 24, 2015|work=WSAW.com|publisher=WSAW-TV|date=June 3, 2014}}</ref> * May 4 – Eddie Andreini was killed during Thunder Over Solano airshow at the [[Travis Air Force Base]] in [[Solano County, California]] in his highly modified PR13D Super Stearman. The fatal accident occurred when he was attempting his signature low-altitude inverted ribbon cutting maneuver.<ref>{{cite web|title=Airshow Pilot, Eddie Andreini, Down at Travis AFB Airshow|url=http://www.aero-news.net/subscribe.cfm?do=main.textpost&id=ec6b5575-3662-4dfd-95d2-7c43e16f2bb2|website=Aero-News Network|publisher=Aero-News Network|accessdate=August 24, 2015|date=May 5, 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|author1=Lee, Stephanie M.|author2=Sernoffsky, Evan|title=Pilot killed in biplane crash at Travis air base show|url=http://www.sfgate.com/bayarea/article/Pilot-killed-in-biplane-crash-at-Travis-air-base-5452405.php|website=San Francisco Chronicle|publisher=[[Hearst Communications, Inc.]]|accessdate=August 24, 2015|date=May 5, 2014}}</ref> * March 7 – [[Tamás Nádas]] died at the Qatar Mile event at the [[Al Khor Airport]] in [[Al Khor]], Qatar. The fatal accident occurred when he was doing an inverted low pass in his [[Zivko Edge 540]]. While in the inverted position, he lost control of his aircraft and plummeted to the ground.<ref>{{cite news|last1=John|first1=Anil|title=‘Schumacher of the sky’ Nadas dies in Al Khor crash|url=http://www.gulf-times.com/qatar/178/details/383834/%E2%80%98schumacher-of-the-sky%E2%80%99-nadas-dies-in-al-khor-crash|accessdate=August 25, 2015|work=Gulf Times|publisher=Gulf Publishing & Printing Company (W.L.L)|date=March 8, 2014}}</ref>
== 2013 == * October 12 – [[Glen Dell]] suffered severe burns when his [[Extra EA-300]] crashed at the Secunda Airshow in [[Secunda, Mpumalanga|Secunda]], Mpumalanga. A few hours later he died of his injuries at the local hospital.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.news24.com/SouthAfrica/News/Aerobatic-pilot-dies-after-show-crash-20131012|title=Aerobatic pilot dies after show crash}}</ref> * August 17 – An [[Interstate L-6 Cadet]] crashed during takeoff while performing at the Lancaster Community Days Air Show at the [[Lancaster Airport (Pennsylvania)|Lancaster Airport]] in [[Lancaster, Pennsylvania]]. The pilot appears to be fine.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://lancasteronline.com/article/local/884268_Plane-crashes-at-Lancaster-Airport--pilot-not-injured.html |title=Archived copy |access-date=June 18, 2017 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130820003054/http://lancasteronline.com/article/local/884268_Plane-crashes-at-Lancaster-Airport--pilot-not-injured.html |archive-date=August 20, 2013 |dead-url=yes |df=mdy-all }}</ref> * June 29 – [[2013 Eberswalde-Finow Zlin crash]] – unnamed pilot, 47, who was piloting the [[Zlín Z 526|Zlín Z-526AFS Akrobat]] at the Rock 'N' Race in [[Finowfurt]], Germany died when the airplane crashed.<ref>[http://www.bz-berlin.de/aktuell/berlin/berliner-kunstflieger-stirbt-bei-absturz-article1701380.html Bei Finowfurt: Berliner Kunstflieger stirbt bei Absturz – B.Z. Berlin]. Bz-berlin.de. Retrieved July 13, 2013.</ref> * June 23 – John Klatt was forced to land his [[MX Aircraft MXS]] after he experienced an engine failure. He released the aircraft's canopy, which had become coated with oil, in order to regain forward visibility to land. He suffered some minor burns and bruises, but was otherwise fine. The aircraft was in need of repairs.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.aero-news.net/index.cfm?do=main.textpost&id=7f0e8522-e6c1-4aff-ba49-d3be9a18d1c7|title=John Klatt Down Safe After Engine Loss During Airshow – Aero-News Network}}</ref> * June 22 – Pilot [[Charlie Schwenker]] and wingwalker [[Jane Wicker]] were killed when Wicker's [[Boeing-Stearman Model 75|Boeing-Stearman IB75A]] struck the ground and burst into flames while performing at the [[Vectren Dayton Air Show]] at the [[Dayton International Airport]] in [[Vandalia, Ohio]]. The fatal accident occurred when the Stearman was transitioning to a low-level inverted pass, with Wicker hanging upside down by her ankles off the lower wing (but sitting right-side up while inverted). While flying inverted from the southeast to the northwest in front of the spectators, the aircraft's nose pitched slightly above the horizon. The aircraft abruptly rolled to the right and impacted terrain in a descending left-wing-low attitude. A post-impact fire ensued and consumed a majority of the right wing and front half of the fuselage.<ref>[http://www.aero-news.net/index.cfm?do=main.textpost&id=0fd8c877-179a-46e5-99e9-cfed16746514 Dayton AirShow Crash Claims Two Airshow Performers | Aero-News Network]. Aero-news.net (June 22, 2013). Retrieved July 13, 2013.</ref> * May 19 – [[Murat Öztürk (aviator)|Murat Öztürk]] crashed his plane while participating for the weekend's Adana Air Show organized to celebrate national public holiday in [[Turkey]].<ref>[http://webtv.hurriyet.com.tr/2/49527/23321067/1/gosteri-ucagi-boyle-dustu.aspx Gösteri Uçaği Böyle Düştü – Hürriyet Tv Haber] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130612025902/http://webtv.hurriyet.com.tr/2/49527/23321067/1/gosteri-ucagi-boyle-dustu.aspx |date=June 12, 2013 }}. ''Hürriyet Daily News''. (May 19, 2013). Retrieved July 13, 2013.</ref> * May 5 – Ladislao Tejedor Romero, an assistant to Spain's [[Spanish Ministry of Defence|Defense Minister]], was severely injured when the [[Hispano HA-200|Hispano HA-200 Saeta]] he piloted crashed into a hangar and exploded on impact at the [[Madrid-Cuatro Vientos Airport]] in Madrid, Spain. A few hours later he died of his injuries at the local hospital.<ref>[http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-2319845/Madrid-air-plane-crash-Horror-thousands-watch-historic-jet-plunge-ground-explode-killing-pilot.html Madrid air show plane crash: Horror as thousands watch historic jet plunge to the ground and explode killing pilot]. ''Daily Mail''. Retrieved July 13, 2013.</ref> Three policemen and a woman who went to help the pilot after the crash were injured.<ref>{{es}} [http://ccaa.elpais.com/ccaa/2013/05/05/madrid/1367756324_631302.html Un piloto muere al estrellarse su avión durante una exhibición], ''www.elpais.com'', May 5, 2013.</ref> * April 7 – First Lieutenant Rafael Sanchez and Second Lieutenant Carlos Manuel Guerrero crashed an [[ENAER T-35 Pillán]] while participating in the Show Aéreo del Caribe in [[Santo Domingo]], Dominican Republic. The aircraft pulled up and rolled inverted, but failed to recover from the dive following the maneuver. The pilot rolled upright, and the aircraft impacted the water, Both pilots died.<ref>[http://www.aero-news.net/index.cfm?do=main.textpost&id=70a7c020-fb12-45c2-b793-bbddf7b6c4f2 Two Pilots Lost In Dominican Republic Air Show Accident | Aero-News Network]. Aero-news.net (April 9, 2013). Retrieved July 13, 2013.</ref> * March 17 – Roger Stokes, who was flying a [[Supermarine Aircraft Spitfire Mk26]], an 80% scale home-build replica of the [[Supermarine Spitfire]], died when it crashed into a fence between two businesses in a commercial area on Frost Road in the nearby suburb of [[Salisbury, South Australia|Salisbury]], while completing a routine at the Classic Jets Original Parafield Airshow at [[Parafield Airport]] in [[Parafield, South Australia|Parafield]], South Australia.<ref>http://www.atsb.gov.au/publications/investigation_reports/2013/aair/ao-2013-051.aspx</ref> * January 23 – [[Kirby Chambliss]] crashed his [[Zivko Edge 540]] while participating for the weekend's Ilopango Air Show in [[El Salvador]]. The incident happened when he was executing a formation high alpha pass and crashed at the end of the runway as the engine quit. The airplane was a total loss and Chambliss survived with bumps and bruises.<ref>[http://www.eaa.org/news/2013/2013-01-23_chambliss-reportedly-ok-after-crash.asp EAA News – Chambliss Reportedly OK After Crash in El Salvador] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131230234110/http://www.eaa.org/news/2013/2013-01-23_chambliss-reportedly-ok-after-crash.asp |date=December 30, 2013 }}. Eaa.org (January 23, 2013). Retrieved July 13, 2013.</ref>
== 2012 ==
* September 29 – An [[FFA AS-202 Bravo|AS/SA 202 Bravo]] piloted by Nurman Lubis and Tonny Haryono, owned by the Indonesian Aerosport Federation, crashed because the plane appeared to be flying too low during its aerobatic routine and spun "out of control" before it hit the structure at the Bandung Air Show at the [[Husein Sastranegara International Airport]] in. Both pilots died.<ref name=JP>{{cite web|url=http://www.thejakartapost.com/news/2012/09/29/two-pilots-die-plane-crash-during-bandung-air-show.html |title=Two pilots die in plane crash during Bandung Air Show |accessdate=January 25, 2017 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120930204259/https://www.thejakartapost.com/news/2012/09/29/two-pilots-die-plane-crash-during-bandung-air-show.html |archivedate=September 30, 2012 |work=The Jakarta Post |date=September 29, 2012}}</ref><ref name=AC>[http://aviationcare.com/component/content/article/38-international-news/3470-two-pilots-die-in-plane-crash-during-bandung-air-show-.html] {{Webarchive|url=https://archive.is/20130117113846/http://aviationcare.com/component/content/article/38-international-news/3470-two-pilots-die-in-plane-crash-during-bandung-air-show-.html |date=January 17, 2013 }} Aviation Care.</ref> * September 11 – A highly modified [[Hawker Sea Fury]], nicknamed "Furias," piloted by [[Matt Jackson (pilot)|Matt Jackson]] made a hard emergency landing when the right landing gear collapsed and veered off the runway at the 2012 [[Reno Air Races|National Championship Air Races and Air Show]] in [[Reno]], [[Nevada]]. The pilot was uninjured.<ref>[http://www.aero-news.net/EmailArticle.cfm?do=main.textpost&id=8d4b04bb-8894-4cf4-8aa9-297aa4f4bc94 Hawker Sea Fury Makes Hard Landing At Reno | Aero-News Network]. Aero-news.net (September 14, 2012). Retrieved July 13, 2013.</ref> * September 1 – Glenn Smith, a member of the HopperFlight Team died at the [[Quad City Air Show]] while executing a crossover break maneuver when his [[Aero L-39 Albatros|Aero L-39C Albatros]] failed to pull out of a 45-degree bank and crashed when flying in formation at the [[Davenport Municipal Airport (Iowa)|Davenport Municipal Airport]] in [[Davenport, Iowa|Davenport]], Iowa.{{citation needed|date=September 2015}} * August 4 – Kent Pietsch crashed his [[Jelly Belly]] 1942 [[Interstate Cadet]] immediately following the Wetaskiwin Air Show in [[Wetaskiwin]], Alberta, Canada. Just after takeoff, the engine quit and he attempted to turn back for the runway but with insufficient altitude he landed adjacent to the runway and the aircraft hit a ditch, which ripped the wing off. Kent was taken to the hospital in stable condition. He has since returned to the airshow circuit.{{citation needed|date=September 2015}} * July 1 – Trevor Roche died at the [[Shuttleworth Collection|Shuttleworth Military Pageant Airshow]] in Bedfordshire, when the 1923 [[de Havilland DH.53 Humming Bird|de Havilland DH.53 Humming Bird G-EBHX]] crashed.<ref>[http://www.huffingtonpost.co.uk/2012/07/02/vintage-aircraft-pilot-trevor-roche-death-probe-launched-biggleswade-bedforshire_n_1642116.html Probe Launched After Vintage Aircraft Pilot's Death]. ''HuffPost''. Retrieved July 13, 2013.</ref> * June 30 – Gianfranco Cicogna-Mozzoni died at the [[Klerksdorp]] Air Show in South Africa when his [[Aero L-39 Albatros]] got into the wake turbulence of the lead aircraft and suffered a compressor stall, followed by a high-speed wing stall, before hitting the ground at a 50-degree angle. The plane exploded on impact.<ref>[http://www.iol.co.za/news/south-africa/gauteng/flamboyant-italian-s-fiery-end-at-air-show-1.1332015 Flamboyant Italian’s fiery end at air show – Gauteng | IOL News]. IOL.co.za (July 2, 2012). Retrieved July 13, 2013.</ref> * June 15 – A [[Christen Eagle]] piloted by Ryland "Buck" Roetman crashed while performing a series of outside snap rolls, when the engine lost oil pressure during a preview for the Legacy Airshow in [[Rexburg]], [[Idaho]]. The pilot guided the airplane onto an adjacent golf course where it skidded and hit a tree. The pilot suffered a sprained ankle; the aircraft was destroyed.<ref>[http://www.foxnews.com/us/2012/06/16/stunt-plane-crashes-at-id-air-show-pilot-survives/ Stunt plane crashes at ID air show; pilot survives]. Fox News (June 16, 2012). Retrieved July 13, 2013.</ref> * June 3 – A [[Fairey Firefly|Fairey Firefly AS.6 WB518]] suffered a landing gear collapse on runway 27R at the Wings over Gillespie airshow in [[El Cajon]], California. The pilot was uninjured.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.10news.com/news/31148555/detail.html | title=Plane Goes Off Runway at Gillespie Field | publisher=10 News.com}}</ref> * April 28 – Martino Wirth died at the Flugplatz Alkersleben airshow in [[Erfurt]], Germany while flying his 1950s era [[Zlín Z 26|Zlín T Trenér 6]] in a formation flight.<ref>[http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-2137432/Spectators-watch-horror-pilot-dies-fireball-crash-losing-control-air-show.html Spectators watch in horror as pilot dies in fireball crash after losing control at air show]. ''Daily Mail''. (January 5, 2012). Retrieved July 13, 2013.</ref>
== 2011 == * October 14 – The fourth prototype [[Xian JH-7A]], ''814'', of the China Flight Test Establishment of the [[People's Liberation Army Air Force]] crashed into a marsh near [[Wei Nan City]], [[Pucheng County, Shaanxi|Pucheng]] in Shaanxi, China, while performing in an airshow associated with the China International General Aviation Convention. The airframe came down about 1 mile (1.6 km.) from [[Pucheng Neifu Airport]]. One pilot ejected safely but the second crewman was killed.<ref>Kaminski, Tom, "CA News: Losses", ''Combat Aircraft'', Ian Allan Publishing Ltd., Hersham, Surrey, UK, US Edition Volume 12, Number 12, page 39.</ref> * September 17 – A [[T-28 Trojan|T-28C Trojan]], N688GR,<ref>''FlyPast'', Key Publishing, Stamford, Lincs, UK, No. 365, December 2011, page 18.</ref> crashed during the Thunder over the Blue Ridge Open House and Air Show in [[Martinsburg, West Virginia]] killing pilot John Mangan.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://journal-news.net/page/content.detail/id/567728/Plane-crashes-at-airshow--pilot-killed.html?nav=5006 | title=Plane crashes at airshow; pilot killed | work=[[The Journal (West Virginia newspaper)|The Journal]]}}</ref> * September 16 – [[2011 Reno Air Races crash]] – Pilot Jimmy Leeward lost control of his highly modified [[P-51D Mustang]], which was named [[The Galloping Ghost (aircraft)|''The Galloping Ghost'']]. ''The Galloping Ghost'' crashed into spectators and was instantly destroyed at the [[Reno Air Races|National Championship Air Races and Air Show]], killing 10 spectators, injuring 69 spectators and instantly killing Leeward. The NTSB critically investigated the incident and found that it was traveling about 445 knots when it experienced a left roll upset at 17.3 Gs when a section of the left elevator trim tab separated in flight. Deteriorated locknut inserts allowed trim tab attachment screws to become loose, ultimately leading to aerodynamic flutter at racing speeds.<ref name="reno">{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2011/09/18/us/reno-air-show-crash.html|title=Investigators Due to Arrive at Deadly Nevada Air Crash Site|author=Jesse McKinley|date=September 17, 2011 |work=The New York Times|accessdate=September 17, 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.google.com/hostednews/ap/article/ALeqM5hEZmBhwNE3MZTkznljNzWHSoo3Mw?docId=9de10c6256ba4c00b8a010e2862045e5 |accessdate=September 19, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110924201223/https://www.google.com/hostednews/ap/article/ALeqM5hEZmBhwNE3MZTkznljNzWHSoo3Mw?docId=9de10c6256ba4c00b8a010e2862045e5 |archivedate=September 24, 2011 |title=10 dead in Nev. air crash shared love of aviation }}</ref><ref>[http://www.ntsb.gov/news/events/2012/reno_nv/index.html Board Meeting on 2011 Reno Air Race Accident]. Ntsb.gov. Retrieved July 13, 2013.</ref> * August 21 – Wing Walker Todd Green fell 200 feet while attempting an aircraft transfer from a [[Boeing-Stearman Model 75|Stearman]] to a [[Hughes 369]] helicopter at the [[Selfridge Air National Guard Base]] Air Show in [[Harrison Township, Michigan]]. He was seriously injured and taken to the hospital, where he was pronounced dead.<ref>{{cite web|title=Wing walker dies after falling 200 feet from plane at Selfridge Air Show|url=http://www.wxyz.com/homepage-showcase/accident-at-selfridge-air-show|website=WXYZ Detroit|publisher=Scripps Media, Inc.|accessdate=August 25, 2015|date=August 22, 2011|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150918021722/http://www.wxyz.com/homepage-showcase/accident-at-selfridge-air-show|archive-date=September 18, 2015|dead-url=yes|df=mdy-all}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Wing Walker Dies After Fall at Michigan Air Show|url=http://www.foxnews.com/us/2011/08/21/wing-walker-dies-after-fall-at-michigan-air-show/|agency=Associated Press|publisher=Fox News Channel|accessdate=August 25, 2015|quote=(graphic video)}}</ref> * August 20 – A Royal Air Force Aerobatic Team "[[Red Arrows]]" aircraft ([[BAE Hawk]] T1) crashed after performing at an air show in [[Bournemouth]], Dorset, United Kingdom. The aircraft was witnessed to have plunged into the ground next to the River Stour, near the village of Throop. The pilot, 33-year-old Flt. Lt. Jon Egging, was killed in the crash.<ref>{{cite news | url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-14602900 |title=Red Arrows pilot dies in Bournemouth Air Festival crash | date=August 20, 2011 | accessdate=August 22, 2011 |work=BBC News}}</ref> * August 20 – Stunt pilot Bryan Jensen was killed when his modified Pitts 12 "The Beast" crashed at the [[Charles B. Wheeler Downtown Airport]] at the Kansas City Airshow in [[Kansas City, Missouri]], around 1:30 pm.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.kmbc.com/news/28926313/detail.html |title=Pilot Dies in KC Air Show |date=August 20, 2011 |accessdate=August 20, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120322003008/http://www.kmbc.com/news/28926313/detail.html |archivedate=March 22, 2012 |df= }}</ref> * July 28 – A [[General Dynamics F-16 Fighting Falcon|General Dynamics F-16C Fighting Falcon]], ''87–296'', of the [[187th Fighter Wing]], [[Alabama Air National Guard]], flying out of [[Montgomery Air National Guard Base]], overruns the runway at [[Wittman Regional Airport]] at the [[EAA AirVenture Oshkosh]] airshow in [[Oshkosh, Wisconsin|Oshkosh]], Wisconsin. The nose gear collapsed, the nose radome broke and the air-frame skidded to a stop. The pilot was uninjured.<ref>{{cite journal|magazine=Sport Aviation|title=Fog on the flight deck led to F-16 overrun at Airventure 2011|page=13|date=April 2012}}</ref> * July 10 – At the [[Imperial War Museum Duxford]] in Cambridgeshire, United Kingdom, a [[North American P-51 Mustang]], "Big Beautiful Doll", piloted by Rob Davies and a [[Douglas A-1 Skyraider]] were involved in a mid-air collision – The Skyraider pilot was able to land safely despite suffering wing damage, Pilot Rob Davies parachuted to safety and his P-51 crashed and was destroyed.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-2013219/Pilot-Rob-Davies-escapes-WW2-fighter-mid-air-collision-airshow.html | location=London | work=Daily Mail | title=Display pilot's incredible escape from World War Two fighter as he bails out after mid-air collision at airshow | date=July 11, 2011}}</ref> * July 9 – A replica [[Fokker Dr.I]] lost power at about {{convert|600|ft|m|abbr=on}} above the ground during a mock dogfight at the Geneseo Air Show. The pilot, 67-year-old Joseph Auger, attempted a controlled powerless glide, but the landing gear got caught on cornstalks and flipped over. The pilot was able to extricate himself from the wreckage and sustained only minor injuries.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.democratandchronicle.com/article/20110710/NEWS01/107100338/Two-planes-damaged-separate-crashes-Geneseo-Air-Show|title=Two planes damaged in separate crashes at Geneseo Air Show|author=Sruthi Gottipati|date=July 10, 2011|publisher=Democrat and Chronicle|accessdate=July 11, 2011}}</ref> * June 18 – Christen Eagle II aircraft crashed into the River Wisla at the Air Show in Plock, Poland. The pilot [[Marek Szufa]] who was also a pilot of Boeing 767 in Polish airlines LOT died three hours later in a hospital. In his life he spent 20 000 hours in the air and took part in many air shows and championships.<ref>{{cite news|title=Air show stunt ends in tragedy in Poland|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/europe/poland/8585019/Air-show-stunt-ends-in-tragedy-in-Poland.html|work=The Telegraph|date=June 19, 2011}}</ref> * June 4 – 71-year-old Bill Phipps, an experienced [[Campbell River, British Columbia|Campbell River]], British Columbia pilot, was severely injured while performing aerobatics at the Wings and Wheels event at [[Nanaimo Airport]], British Columbia.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www2.canada.com/nanaimodailynews/story.html?id=2759a141. | title=Friends recall pilot's affection for his homemade biplane. As Bill Phipps recovers from his injuries, flying buddy thinks taking plane too low increased danger | publisher=Nanaimo Daily news | date=June 7, 2011 | accessdate=June 23, 2011 }}{{Dead link|date=September 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> * March 26 – A [[Yakovlev Yak-52]] crashed during the "Wings Over Flagler" airshow held at [[Flagler County Airport]] in Florida. It is reported that 58-year-old "Wild Bill" Walker experienced [[G-LOC]] during an aerobatic "heart" maneuver and was fatally injured in the resulting crash.<ref>http://www.ntsb.gov/aviationquery/GenPDF.aspx?id=ERA11FA214&rpt=fa</ref> * March 12 – While performing their Pirated Skies wing walking act, Kyle and Amanda Franklin were severely injured when their [[Waco F series|Waco JMF-7]] nicknamed "Mystery Ship", suffered an apparent engine failure at the CAF 2011 Air Fiesta in Brownsville, TX. Both were listed as in stable condition with burns covering more than 60% of their bodies. Kyle's burns were not as serious as first reported. Amanda had successful surgery March 16, and was believed to have a good recovery chance at that time, but died on May 27.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.aopa.org/aircraft/articles/2011/110528airshow_performer_amanda_franklin_dies.html |title=Wing walker Amanda Franklin dies |publisher=AOPA Online |date=May 28, 2011 |accessdate=June 3, 2011}}</ref>
== 2010 == * September 5 – A woman was killed when a [[De Havilland Tiger Moth]] biplane crashed into spectators at an air show in southern Germany at the Airport [[Lauf-Lillinghof]] near [[Nuremberg]]. 38 people were injured in the accident, five of them seriously.<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/world/europe/1-dead-33-injured-after-plane-crashes-into-audience-at-german-air-show/article1696841/ |location=Toronto |work=The Globe and Mail |title=1 dead, 33 injured after plane crashes into audience at German air show |accessdate=August 30, 2013}}</ref> Four years later, a trial in Hersbrucker District Court determined that the cause of the crash was pilot error, finding the pilot guilty of "… fahrlässiger Tötung und fahrlässiger Körperverletzung …" (involuntary manslaughter and negligent injury)."<ref>{{cite web|title=Flugunfall Lillinghof Strafbefehl gegen Piloten erlassen (Aircraft Accident Lillinghof issued charges against pilots) |url=http://www.br.de/nachrichten/mittelfranken/inhalt/strafbefehl-flugzeug-absturz-lillinghof-100.html |website=BR Mittelfranken |publisher=Bayerischer Rundfunk |accessdate=August 25, 2015 |date=September 12, 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150525054737/http://www.br.de/nachrichten/mittelfranken/inhalt/strafbefehl-flugzeug-absturz-lillinghof-100.html |archivedate=May 25, 2015 |df= }}</ref> * August 22 – Mike Newman escaped with only three cracked vertebrae after crashing a [[Swift S-1]] aerobatic glider on the runway at an airshow at [[Shoreham-by-Sea]]<ref>{{cite journal |journal=Daily Mail |title=Air show crash drama: Pilot's amazing escape as stunt glider smashes into runway as 15,000 fans look on |date=August 2010 |url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-1311828/Shoreham-air-crash-pilot-escapes-stunt-glider-smashes-runway.html |accessdate=October 31, 2014 }}</ref> * April 2 – Pilot Captain Anderson Amaro Fernandes was killed when an [[Embraer EMB 312 Tucano]] belonging to the "Esquadrilha da Fumaça" aerobatic team of the [[Brazilian Air Force]] crashed while performing at a ceremony for 68 years of the [[Lages]] aero club in [[Santa Catarina (state)|Santa Catarina]], Brazil.{{citation needed|date=September 2015}} * March 3 – Pilot Commander Suresh Kumar Maurya and his co-pilot Lieutenant Commander Rahul Nair were killed when an [[HAL Kiran]] aircraft belonging to the [[Sagar Pawan]] [[aerobatic]] team of the [[Indian Navy]] crashed while performing at the opening ceremony of the India Aviation Show at [[Hyderabad, India]].{{citation needed|date=September 2015}}
== 2009 == * November 14 – Overberg Airshow ([[Bredasdorp]], South Africa) – An [[English Electric Lightning]] of [[Thunder City]] experienced a rear fuselage fire leading to hydraulic failure while performing. The pilot tried to get the aircraft back to base; after failure of the canopy jettison system he was unable to use the ejection seat and the aircraft crashed killing the pilot, Dave Stock, 46.<ref>{{cite news |title= Jet crashes at air show – explodes |url= http://www.news24.com/Content/SouthAfrica/News/1059/fef0a403d68f4a148bf5a1277c26ceb5/14-11-2009-03-31/Jet_crashes_at_air_show_-_explodes |access-date= June 18, 2017 |archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20100106175001/http://www.news24.com/Content/SouthAfrica/News/1059/fef0a403d68f4a148bf5a1277c26ceb5/14-11-2009-03-31/Jet_crashes_at_air_show_-_explodes |archive-date= January 6, 2010 |dead-url= yes |df= mdy-all }}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Killed air show pilot named |url=http://www.news24.com/Content/SouthAfrica/News/1059/4d6c6e4021074e3a863b77fc098c492e/14-11-2009-05-34/Killed_air_show_pilot_named |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091116103619/http://www.news24.com/Content/SouthAfrica/News/1059/4d6c6e4021074e3a863b77fc098c492e/14-11-2009-05-34/Killed_air_show_pilot_named |archivedate=November 16, 2009 |df= }}</ref> * September 6 – Brixia Airshow ([[Montichiari]], Italy) – A [[Mudry CAP 10|CAP-10B]] aircraft hit the ground while performing low altitude [[aerobatics]]. Of the two pilots, Marzio Maccarana, 26, was killed and Paolo Castellani, 55, was injured.<ref>[http://www.md80.it/2009/09/06/precipita-un-velivolo-al-brixia-airshow-di-montichiari-bs/ Archivio Blog – Precipita Un Velivolo Al Brixia Airshow Di Montichiari (Bs)]. md80.it (July 24, 2009). Retrieved July 13, 2013.</ref> * August 30 – Radom Air Show ([[Radom]], [[Poland]]) – A [[Sukhoi Su-27]] aircraft from [[Belarus]] crashed while performing an air display, killing both pilots, Col. Alexander Morfintsky and Col. Alexander Zhuravlevich.{{citation needed|date=September 2015}} * July 4 – 4 Air Show ([[Tehachapi, California]]) – Pilot Dave Zweigle's [[Aero L-29 Delfín|L-29 Delfín]] crashed while making low altitude passes during the airshow. Zweigle and passenger Robert Chamberlain were killed in the accident.<ref>{{cite web| title = L-29 Down in CA Air Show Accident| website = Aero-News.net| publisher = The Aero-News Network| date = July 6, 2009| url = http://www.aero-news.net/index.cfm?ContentBlockID=e15295f8-297c-4acd-b6aa-96447e3fd710}}</ref>
==2008== * June 1 – Lake Bracciano Air Show ([[Lake Bracciano]] – [[Province of Rome]], Italy) – Aircraft Commander Captain Filippo Fornassi was killed and co-pilot Captain Fabio Manzella was injured when their [[NH Industries]] [[NHI NH90|NH90]] tactical transport helicopter struck the water and sank into [[Lake Bracciano]]. The crash happened while the helicopter was diving after completing a [[Fieseler (aerobatics)|Fieseler Maneuver]].<ref>{{cite web| last = Peruzzi| first = Luca| title = Italian army NH90 TTH fatal crash; no flying restrictions to remaining fleet| work = Flight International |date = June 5, 2008 | url = http://www.flightglobal.com/articles/2008/06/05/224481/picture.html| accessdate =June 27, 2008}}</ref> * May 10 – Modesto Airport Appreciation Day ([[Modesto, California]]) – Pilot Rob Harrison was injured when the [[Moravan|Moravan Otrokovice]] [[Zlin Z-50|Zlin 50LX]] aircraft he was piloting crashed while performing a roll maneuver.<ref>{{cite news| last = Selna | first = Robert | title = Stunt pilot in hospital after air-show crash | work = San Francisco Chronicle| date = May 11, 2008| url = http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=/c/a/2008/05/10/BAKN10KGQF.DTL&feed=rss.bayarea | accessdate = June 25, 2008}}</ref> * April 26 – Kindel Air Field ([[Eisenach|Kindel]], Germany) – A [[Zlin Z-37 Cmelak]] left the runway on takeoff and veered into a crowd of spectators, killing two and injuring eighteen.<ref>{{cite web|title=Air show plane crash in Germany kills one, injures 10 | publisher = China View.cn| url = http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/2008-04/27/content_8059181.htm| accessdate =June 26, 2008}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.bfu-web.de/DE/Publikationen/Untersuchungsberichte/2008/Bericht_08_3X023-LetZ37A-Eisenach-Kindel-Flugtag.pdf?__blob=publicationFile|title=Accident report|last=|first=|date=|website=bfu-web.de|access-date=}}</ref> * April 26 – Spirit of Flight 2008 Air Show ([[Galveston, Texas]]) – A [[Supermarine Spitfire]] taxied into the rear of a recently restored [[Hawker Hurricane]] at the [[Lone Star Flight Museum]] airshow. No injuries were reported.<ref>{{cite web| last = Rice| first = Harvey|author2=Eric Hanson | title = Ground collision damages vintage airplanes| work = Houston Chronicle |date=April 29, 2008 |url=http://www.chron.com/CDA/archives/archive.mpl?id=2008_4558183 |accessdate=July 12, 2009}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title = Spirit of Flight 2008 Air Show crash |work=Lone Star Flight Museum/Discuss |url=https://www.flickr.com/groups/lone_star_flight_museum/discuss/72157604811081650/ |accessdate=July 12, 2009}}</ref><ref>[http://www.ntsb.gov/ntsb/brief.asp?ev_id=20080505X00589&key=1 NTSB Report for April 26, 2008 ground collision in Galveston, Texas]</ref> * August 18 – Vincent Nasta of Wading River, N.Y. was flying a replica French WW1 Nieuport 24 in a simulated dogfight with a German plane on Sunday afternoon when it crashed about 1,000 feet from the Old Rhinebeck Aerodrome, authorities said. The plane landed in a wooded area and caught fire. Nasta, 47, was the sole occupant.<ref>{{cite web| title = Veteran Pilot Dead After Crash in New York Air Show| publisher = Fox News Channel| date = August 18, 2008| url = http://www.foxnews.com/story/0,2933,405721,00.html}}</ref>
==2007== * September 15 – [[Shoreham Airshow]] ([[West Sussex]], England) – Pilot Brian Brown was killed when the [[Hawker Hurricane]] he was flying failed to pull out of a dive during a mock [[dogfight]].<ref>{{cite web | url=http://news.sky.com/skynews/article/0,,70131-1284268,00.html | title=Pilot Dies in Sussex Airshow Crash | publisher=Sky News | accessdate=June 27, 2008}}</ref> * September 1 – [[Radom Air Show]] (Radom, Poland) – Pilots Piotr Banachowicz and Lech Marchelewski were killed in the mid-air collision of their [[Zlin Z-526]] aircraft.{{citation needed|date=September 2015}} * July 28 – [[Dayton Air Show]] ([[Dayton, Ohio]]) – [[Jim LeRoy]] was killed when his [[Pitts Special|S2S Bulldog II]] crashed at the end of the runway while performing a [[Aerobatic maneuver|1/2 Cuban 8]] and snap rolls.<ref>[http://www.whiotv.com/news/13774845/detail.html Dayton Air Show Crash Kills Pilot – News Story – WHIO Dayton] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081201231032/http://www.whiotv.com/news/13774845/detail.html |date=December 1, 2008 }}</ref> The reason for this crash was reported as pilot error by the [[NTSB]].<ref>{{cite web|last=Nolan |first=John |title=Federal inquiry cites pilot error in fatal Dayton Air Show crash |publisher=airportbusiness.com |date=June 20, 2008 |url=http://www.airportbusiness.com/online/article.jsp?siteSection=1&id=20661 |accessdate=September 19, 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110707100453/http://www.airportbusiness.com/online/article.jsp?siteSection=1&id=20661 |archivedate=July 7, 2011 |df= }}</ref> * July 27 – [[Experimental Aircraft Association]]'s [[AirVenture]] show ([[Oshkosh, Wisconsin]]) – While approaching the runway for a landing, pilot Gerry Beck's scratch-built [[P-51 Mustang|P-51A Mustang]] overtook and struck a [[P-51 Mustang|P-51D Mustang]] that had touched down ahead of him. Beck's plane flipped over and crashed along the runway, killing him. The other pilot was not injured, although his P-51D was pushed on its nose and sustained damage to the tail.<ref>{{cite news| title = 1 Killed in Wisconsin Airshow Crash| work = The Washington Post | agency = Associated Press| date = July 28, 2007 <!-- ; 2:58 am --> |url= https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2007/07/27/AR2007072701821.html| accessdate = June 26, 2008}}</ref><ref>{{cite web| title = 311 N8082U 'Precious Metal II'| work = P-51 Mustang Survivors| publisher = MustangsMustangs| url = http://www.mustangsmustangs.com/p-51/survivors/pages/43-BeckA.shtml| accessdate = June 26, 2008}}</ref> * June 24 – Galway Air Show ([[Galway]], Ireland) – Three people on the ground were injured when the door from a hovering RAF helicopter flew off and plunged into a large crowd below.<ref>{{cite web|title=Two investigations into airshow accident|publisher=RTÉ News|date=June 25, 2007|url=http://www.rte.ie/news/2007/0625/aviation.html|accessdate=February 7, 2009|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070912073040/http://www.rte.ie/news/2007/0625/aviation.html|archive-date=September 12, 2007|dead-url=yes|df=mdy-all}}</ref> * April 21 – [[2007 Blue Angels South Carolina crash|Blue Angels crash]] ([[Marine Corps Air Station Beaufort]], [[Beaufort, South Carolina]]) – Lieutenant Commander Kevin 'Kojak' Davis of the [[Blue Angels]] was killed when he grayed out and lost control of his [[F/A-18 Hornet]].{{citation needed|date=September 2015}} * March 16 – Tico Airshow ([[Titusville, Florida]]) – Pilot Eilon Krugman-Kadi was killed when the [[Aero L-39|Aero L-39 Albatros]] he was piloting crashed while performing a loop.<ref>{{cite web|title=Pilot Killed in Crash at Airshow |publisher=News 13 Central Florida |date=March 19, 2007 |url=http://www.cfnews13.com/News/Local/2007/3/16/jet_crash_at_airshow.html |accessdate=June 25, 2008 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080211233822/http://www.cfnews13.com/News/Local/2007/3/16/jet_crash_at_airshow.html |archivedate=February 11, 2008 |deadurl=no}}</ref>
==2006== [[File:Hawker Hunter Hillsboro Air Show Crash2.JPG|thumb|Smoke from a crashed [[Hawker Hunter]] at the Oregon International Airshow Hillsboro, Oregon July 16, 2006]] * October 14 – Culpeper Airfest ([[Culpeper Regional Airport]], [[Culpeper, Virginia]]) – Pilot [[Nancy Lynn]] was severely burned when the wingtip of her [[Extra 300]]L struck the ground and burst into flames after performing multiple snap rolls on a downline. Lynn succumbed to her injuries later that night at the [[University of Virginia Health System|University of Virginia Medical Center]] in [[Charlottesville, Virginia]]. Lynn's son Pete Muntean was narrating her routine when the accident occurred.<ref>{{cite web| title = Accident claims aerobatic star Nancy Lynn |publisher=AOPA Online |date = October 19, 2006| url = http://www.aopa.org/whatsnew/newsitems/2006/061016lynn.html |accessdate=June 28, 2008}}</ref> * October 4 – Tucumcari Air Show ([[Tucumcari, New Mexico]]) – Pilot Guy "Doc" Baldwin was killed when he lost control of his [[Extra 300]]L while performing a loop.<ref>{{cite news |title=Pilot Dies in N.M. Air Show Crash |publisher=Fox News Channel |date=October 4, 2006 |url=http://www.foxnews.com/printer_friendly_wires/2006Oct04/0,4675,AirShowFatality,00.html |accessdate=June 25, 2008}}</ref> <!-- * September 22 – ([[Cape Town, South Africa]]) – Pilot Martin Van Straaten of the [[Sasol|Sasol Tigers]] aerobatic team was killed when the Aero Vodochody [[L-29 Delfin]] jet trainer he was flying crashed into [[Table Bay]] during a practice flight. He had ejected at too low an altitude prior to the crash.<ref>{{cite web |title=Pilot dies after ditching jet |publisher=Ysterplaat Air Force Base, Cape Town | url = http://www.milnerton.info/nearbySuburbs/Ysterplaat/AirforceBase/YsterplaatAirforceBase.htm| accessdate = February 7, 2009}}</ref> --> * September 10 – [[Aero GP]] of Malta ([[Marsamxett Harbour]], [[Malta]]) – Pilot [[Gabor Varga]] was killed when the [[Yakovlev Yak-55|Yak-55]] aircraft he was piloting was involved in a mid-air collision with another aircraft. Eddie Goggins, who was piloting an [[Extra 200]], received minor injuries.<ref>{{cite web| title = Stunt pilot dies in crash over Marsamxett| work = MaltaMedia News | publisher = MaltaMedia Online Network| date = September 10, 2006| url = http://www.maltamedia.com/news/2005/ln/article_11464.shtml| accessdate =July 6, 2008}}</ref> * July 30 – [[Experimental Aircraft Association]]'s [[AirVenture]] show ([[Oshkosh, Wisconsin]]) – The passenger of a [[Van's Aircraft RV-6]] was killed when the propeller of a [[Grumman TBF Avenger|Grumman TBM-3 Avenger]] cut into the fuselage of the RV-6. Both aircraft were taxiing for takeoff at the time of the accident. No injuries were reported from the occupants of the Avenger.<ref>{{cite news|title=Crashes Mar Wisconsin Airshow|publisher=CBS News|date=July 30, 2006|url=http://www.cbsnews.com/stories/2006/07/30/national/main1847596.shtml?source=RSS&attr=U.S._1847596|accessdate=June 29, 2008}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=NTSB Identification: CHI06FA206B|work=NTSB|date=June 25, 2007|url=http://www.ntsb.gov/ntsb/brief.asp?ev_id=20060804X01093&key=2|accessdate=June 29, 2008}}</ref> * July 23 – [[Spanish Guardia Civil]] ([[Vigo, Galicia, Spain]]) Helicopter crashed on the beach during air show.<ref>http://www.abc.es/hemeroteca/historico-23-07-2006/abc/Nacional/un-helicoptero-guardia-civil-cae-al-mar-en-un-accidente-sin-heridos_1422573176183.html</ref><ref>https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=_JNqKecaPeM</ref> * July 16 – [[Oregon International Airshow]] ([[Hillsboro, Oregon]]) – Pilot Robert E. Guilford was killed when his [[Hawker Hunter|Hawker-Siddeley Hunter Mk 58]] lost power and crashed into a residence. Guilford was leaving the airshow on a return trip home.<ref>{{cite web |last=Tareen |first=Sophia |author2=Stuart Tomlinson |title = It just fell out of the sky |work=The Oregonian |date=July 17, 2006 |url=http://blog.oregonlive.com/washingtoncounty/2007/12/fatal_2006_air_show_crash.html |accessdate=June 25, 2008}}</ref> * May 5 – Children's Day flight exhibition ([[Suwon Air Base]], [[South Korea]]) – Captain Kim Do-hyun of the [[Republic of Korea Air Force]]'s [[Black Eagle team|Black Eagles]] display team was killed when he lost control of his [[Cessna A-37 Dragonfly|Cessna A-37B Dragonfly]].<ref>{{cite web |last=Mitchell |first=Terence |title=Pilot Deaths Put F-15 Deal in Doubt – Korea stunned by deaths of 3 pilots in less than a month |publisher=Ohmynews |date=June 10, 2006 |url=http://english.ohmynews.com/ArticleView/article_view.asp?menu=A11100&no=297645&rel_no=1&back_url |accessdate=July 6, 2008}}</ref>
==2005== *August 24 – Thunder in the Air Airshow warm-up – ([[Thunder Bay, Ontario]]) – Capt. Andrew Mackay of the [[Canadian Forces Snowbirds]] safely ejected from his aircraft.<ref>[http://www.airforce.forces.gc.ca/dfs-dsv/nr-sp/index-eng.asp?id=10070 "Canadian Forces Flight Safety Report: CT114120 Tutor."] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110611173708/http://www.airforce.forces.gc.ca/dfs-dsv/nr-sp/index-eng.asp?id=10070 |date=June 11, 2011 }} ''airforce.forces.gc.ca'', August 24, 2005. Retrieved September 19, 2011.</ref><ref>Bridges, Holly. [http://www.forces.gc.ca/site/commun/ml-fe/vol_8/vol8_31/831_full.pdf "Snowbird safely ejects, Flight Safety investigation continues, p. 12."] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110916013435/http://www.forces.gc.ca/site/commun/ml-fe/vol_8/vol8_31/831_full.pdf |date=September 16, 2011 }} ''Maple Leaf, Vol 8., No. 31. p. 12. September 8, 2005'' via ''airforce.forces.gc.ca''. Retrieved September 19, 2011.</ref> *July 26 – Wittman Regional Airport (Oshkosh, Wisconsin) – Pilot Richard James was killed when his North American F-51D crashed while waiting in a holding pattern to perform a "missing man" formation flyover at an airshow.<ref>{{cite web|title=P-51 Mustang News Fatal P-51 Crash During EAA Airventure|url=http://www.mustangsmustangs.com/p-51/news/james_072605|website=''mustangsmustangs.com''|accessdate=June 18, 2017}}</ref> *July 23 – Wings-over-Oklahoma Air Show (Claremore, Oklahoma) – The pilot of a Yakovlev Yak 52 was killed when he crashed inverted and the aircraft caught fire while flying over the runway.<ref>{{cite web|title=N2331C accident description|url=http://planecrashmap.com/plane/ok/N2331C/|website=''Planecrashmap.com''|accessdate=June 18, 2017}}</ref> * July 10 – Moose Jaw Air Show ([[Moose Jaw, Saskatchewan]]) – Pilots [[Jimmy Franklin]] and [[Bobby Younkin]] were killed in a mid-air collision during a dogfight routine. At the time of the accident, Franklin was piloting a [[Waco Aircraft Company|Waco]] [[Waco F series|UPF-7]] biplane, and Youkin was piloting a [[Wolf-Samson]] biplane, a 1980s replica of the 1948 [[Curtis Pitts|Pitts Samson]].<ref>{{cite web| last = Craft| first = Dan| title = Report: Pilots Tried To Avoid Collision Younkin, Franklin Died In Aerobatic Routine| publisher = The Morning News| date = April 4, 2006| url = http://www.nwaonline.net/articles/2006/04/11/news/02fzyounkin.txt | accessdate =June 29, 2008}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | title = Accident report for July 10, 2005 Moose Jaw mid-air collision | work = Report Number A05C0123 | publisher = [[Transportation Safety Board of Canada]] | url = http://www.tsb.gc.ca/eng/rapports-reports/aviation/2005/a05c0123/a05c0123.asp | accessdate = September 23, 2009}}</ref>
==2004== * October 15 – Marine Corps Air Station Miramar Air Show ([[Miramar, San Diego, California|Miramar, California]]) – Stunt pilot Sean DeRosier was killed when his "Cabo Wabo SkyRocker" failed to pull out of a dive.<ref>{{cite news| last =City| first =Bay| title = Fairfield stunt pilot killed in air show crash| work =San Francisco Chronicle| date = October 15, 2004| url = http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=/g/a/2004/10/15/pilot15.DTL |accessdate=July 12, 2009}}</ref> *October 2 – Santa Fe Municipal Airport – Pilot Richard Bobbitt was killed when his 1993 Sukhoi SU-29 stalled and crashed while performing a torque roll.<ref>{{cite news|title=Pilot Blamed for Crash that Killed Him at Santa Fe Air Show|url=https://www.abqjournal.com/news/apcrash11-05-05.htm|accessdate=June 18, 2017|work=Albuquerque Journal|agency=Associated Press|date=November 5, 2005}}</ref> *April 30 – [[Air & Sea Show|Fort Lauderdale Air & Sea Show]] – Featured performer Ian Groom died while practicing for the show when his [[Sukhoi Su-31]] dove into the Atlantic Ocean after performing a flat spin.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Kaye|first1=Ken|last2=Olmeda|first2=Rafael|last3=Hernandez|first3=Jaime|last4=Fleshler|first4=David|title=Air Show Pilot Killed|url=http://articles.sun-sentinel.com/2004-05-01/news/0405010274_1_air-show-sea-show-ian-groom|publisher=[[The Sun Sentinel]]|accessdate=July 7, 2017|date=May 1, 2004}}</ref>
==2003==
* September 15 – Gunfighter Skies Air Show ([[Mountain Home, Idaho]]) – Pilot error was blamed for the crash of a [[US Air Force Thunderbirds]] [[F-16C]]. The official report states that the pilot "misinterpreted the altitude required to complete the "Split S" maneuver". The pilot successfully ejected and suffered minor injuries. No other injuries were reported.<ref>{{cite web| last = Dewitte| first = Lieven| title = Thunderbird crashes at Idaho air show| work = F-16 Mishap News| publisher = F-16.net| date = September 15, 2003 | url = http://www.f-16.net/news_article842.html| accessdate =June 29, 2008}}</ref><ref>{{cite web| last = jetech| title = Thunderbird accident report released| work = F-16 Mishap News| publisher = F-16.Net| date = January 22, 2004| url = http://www.f-16.net/news_article968.html| accessdate = June 29, 2008}}</ref> *September 13 - Moffett Federal Airfield (Mountain View, California) - A pilot suffered minor injuries when his Aviat Pitts S-2C biplane crashed inverted following the wing striking the ground while performing low altitude rolls.<ref>{{cite web|title=September 13, Mountain View, Calif. / Pitts S-2C|url=http://www.aviationsafetymagazine.com/issues/23_12/|website=Aviation Safety|publisher=Aviation Safety Magazine|accessdate=June 18, 2017}}</ref> * July 12 – Flying Legends Air Show ([[Duxford]], Cambridgeshire, England) – Lieutenant Commander Bill Murton and Neil Rix were killed when the [[Fairey Firefly]] they were in went into a nosedive and never recovered. The plane crashed on the eastern side of the [[M11 motorway]].<ref>{{cite news| title =Air show deaths inquiry starts| work =BBC News International Version |date =July 13, 2003| url =http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/uk_news/england/cambridgeshire/3061391.stm| accessdate = February 7, 2009}}</ref> * May 31 – Coventry Classic Airshow ([[Coventry]], West Midlands, England) – Swedish pilot Pierre Holländer was killed when his homebuilt replica of [[Charles Lindbergh]]'s [[Spirit of St. Louis]] aircraft crashed. The right wing of the plane broke up at altitude about 100 feet.<ref>{{cite news |title=Pilot killed in air show crash |work=BBC News International Version |date=June 1, 2003 |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/uk_news/england/west_midlands/2953268.stm |accessdate=February 7, 2009}}</ref> *March 22 – Gulf Coast Salute 2003 Airshow (Panama City, Florida) – Pilot Chris Smisson was killed when his [[Technoavia SP-95]] failed to recover from performing a loop and crashed.<ref>{{cite news|title=Tyndall AFB Airshow Accident Claims SP-95 Pilot, Chris Smisson|url=http://www.aero-news.net/index.cfm?do=main.textpost&id=d23d5300-8746-4ae1-83e5-0a85a1834eba|accessdate=June 18, 2017|publisher=Aero News Network|date=March 22, 2003}}</ref>
==2002== * November 10 – Celebrate Freedom Festival Airshow ([[Columbia, South Carolina]]) – Pilot Joe Tobul was killed when his [[F4U Corsair|F4U-4 Corsair]] lost power and crashed in a field. At the time of the crash, the plane was part of a flyover formation.<ref>{{cite news|title=Joe Tobul: Well-known Warbird pilot dies in Corsair crash |work=Air Classics, February 2003 |publisher=Challenge Publications Inc. |date=February 2003 |url=http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_qa3901/is_200302/ai_n9191347 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080804090045/http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_qa3901/is_200302/ai_n9191347 |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2008-08-04 |accessdate=July 6, 2008}}</ref> * October 2 – Dabolim Naval Air Base, [[Goa]], India. During the squadron Silver Jubilee Celebrations, two [[Indian Navy]] [[Ilyushin Il-38]], IN302 and IN304 collided in mid-air while flying in formation, killing all twelve occupants on board the two aircraft (six on each). The planes were flying parallel to each other in close formation in front of many naval high-ranking officials and their families when their wings touched.{{citation needed|date=September 2015}} *September 29 – Pickaway County Memorial Airport (Circleville, Ohio) – The pilot of a North American AT-6D was killed when his aircraft stalled and crashed, while climbing and turning, following a low level formation flyover.<ref>{{cite web|title=N29930 accident description|url=http://planecrashmap.com/plane/oh/N29930/|website=''Planecrashmap.com''|accessdate=June 18, 2017}}</ref> * August 2 – Lowestoft Seafront Air Festival ([[Lowestoft]], Suffolk, England) – Flight Lieutenant Tony Cann safely ejected from the [[Harrier GR7]] he was piloting after an engine failure. He was performing a 'bow' maneuver at an approximate altitude of 50 feet over the sea at the time of the accident.<ref>{{cite news|title=Air show Harrier crashes into sea|work=BBC News World Edition|date=August 2, 2002|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/uk_news/england/2168921.stm|accessdate=February 7, 2009}}</ref> Footage of the air show Crash was featured on various reality television shows, such as [[Destroyed In Seconds]] (2008-09) and [[Most Daring]] (2007-2010). * July 27 – [[Sknyliv airshow disaster]] ([[Sknyliv|Sknyliv Airfield]] [[Lviv]], [[Ukraine]]) – Pilot Volodymyr Toponar and co-pilot Yuriy Yegorov of the [[Ukrainian Air Force]] demonstration team the [[Ukrainian Falcons]] ejected from their [[Sukhoi Su-27]] after the left wing struck the ground during a low altitude roll maneuver. The aircraft then struck a parked [[Ilyushin Il-76]] transport and cartwheeled into a crowd of spectators killing 77, including 19 children and injuring over 500.{{citation needed|date=September 2015}} * July 21 – Charity Airshow for Thames Valley Air Ambulance ([[Berkshire, England|Berkshire]], England) – A pilot was injured when his [[de Havilland Tiger Moth]] biplane lost altitude rapidly and crash-landed, throwing the 55-year-old pilot clear of the wreckage.<ref>{{cite news| title =Pilot airlifted to hospital |work=BBC News World Edition | date = July 22, 2002| url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/uk_news/england/2143652.stm |accessdate=February 7, 2009}}</ref> * July 20 – [[Royal International Air Tattoo|Royal International Air Tattoo (RIAT) airshow]] ([[Fairford]], Gloucestershire, England) – An Italian [[Aeritalia G.222]] transport made a hard landing which collapsed the nose landing gear. A small fire erupted but was quickly extinguished. No injuries were reported.<ref>{{cite news| title = Runway fire grounds planes at airshow|work=BBC News| date =July 20, 2002 |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk/england/2140758.stm| accessdate =June 28, 2008}}</ref> * April 20 – Point Mugu air show ([[Point Mugu, California]]) – Navy pilot Commander Michael Norman and radar intercept officer Marine Corps Captain Andrew Muhs were killed when their [[McDonnell-Douglas]] [[F-4 Phantom II|QF-4S+ Phantom II]] stalled and crashed after pulling away from a diamond formation. The Navy report stated in part: "The cause of this tragic accident was the failure of the pilot to manage the energy state of the aircraft, and then to recognize a departure from controlled flight at low altitude, and apply the [[NATOPS]] recovery techniques."<ref>{{cite web| title =QF-4S+ Crash at Pt Mugu – April 20, 2002 | publisher =Goleta Air and Space Museum. | url =http://www.air-and-space.com/20020420%20Pt%20Mugu%20QF-4J%20Crash.htm | accessdate =June 27, 2008}}</ref>
==2001== * July 9 – Sarnia International Airshow ([[Sarnia]], Ontario, Canada) – Pilot Carey Moore was killed when his newly restored Hawker Sea Fury stalled during a tight bank just east of the airport, crashing into a soybean field. Pilot Moore was about to commence his third pass when he lost power while banking to return to show centre.<ref>{{cite news| title = Crash kills air show pilot| publisher = CBC News| date = July 8, 2001| url = http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/crash-kills-air-show-pilot-1.269128}}</ref> * June 4 – ([[Rouen|Rouen, France]]) – Pilot Martin Sargeant was killed while making an emergency landing in his [[Supermarine Spitfire]], due to engine failure. He tried to land on the designated emergency grass strip, but it was occupied by spectators. In an attempt to turn to a hard runway, his aircraft stalled and crashed.<ref>"Sargeant Spitfire verdict delivered", ''Aeroplane Monthly'', June 2002, p. 4</ref><ref>{{cite news| title = Third fatal airshow crash|work=BBC News| date = June 5, 2001 | url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/low/europe/1370860.stm| access-date =July 12, 2009}}</ref> * June 3 – During the [[London Biggin Hill Airport|Biggin Hill]] Airshow a 1944 [[Bell P-63 Kingcobra]] crashed killing the pilot, former Red Arrow Guy Bancroft-Wilson. The American [[World War II]] fighter aircraft had been flying an unplanned sequence, when the pilot lost control at the top of a climbing manoeuvre and was unable to recover from the resulting dive. The aircraft impacted the ground to the west of the runway in a steep nose down attitude.<ref>{{cite web|format=PDF|title=AAIB report into June 3, 2001 accident at Biggin Hill|url=http://www.aaib.gov.uk/cms_resources/dft_avsafety_pdf_500062.pdf|accessdate=November 20, 2009}} (PDF)</ref> The incident was captured on video.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=727Q2fDVXRQ|title=P-63 Crash at Biggin Hill 2001(Fatal)}}</ref> * June 2 – During the [[London Biggin Hill Airport|Biggin Hill]] Airshow a vintage [[de Havilland]] [[de Havilland Vampire|Vampire]] jet crashed, killing both pilots. The Vampire had been flying a display in tandem with a [[de Havilland Sea Vixen|Sea Vixen]], the likely cause of the accident was that the Vampire's flight path had been disrupted by [[wake turbulence]] from the larger aircraft.<ref>{{cite web|format=PDF|title=AAIB report into June 2, 2001 accident at Biggin Hill|url=http://www.aaib.gov.uk/cms_resources/dft_avsafety_pdf_507791.pdf|accessdate=November 20, 2009}} (PDF)</ref> *August 11 – During an airshow in [[Michelstadt]], [[Germany]], a [[Fokker Dr.I|Fokker Dr.1]] [[replica]] [[triplane]] crashed into a field outside the show area, killing the pilot.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.eberbach-channel.de/art_ausgabe.php?id=2126|title=Flugzeugabsturz in Michelstadt...|website=www.eberbach-channel.de|access-date=2018-08-28}}</ref> The [[German Federal Bureau of Aircraft Accident Investigation|BFU]] report says that the cause of the accident was a damaged piece of metal in the vertical stabilizer that broke during flight and made the vertical stabilizer, and in consequence the whole plane, uncontrollable.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.bfu-web.de/DE/Publikationen/Untersuchungsberichte/2001/Bericht_CX010-0.01.pdf?__blob=publicationFile|title=Untersuchungsbericht|last=|first=|date=|website=bfu-web.de|access-date=}}</ref>
==See also== *[[List of air show accidents and incidents in the 20th century]] *[[List of accidents and incidents involving commercial aircraft]] *[[List of air shows]] *[[List of news aircraft accidents and incidents]] *[[Lists of accidents and incidents involving military aircraft]]
==References== {{reflist}}
{{Lists of aviation accidents and incidents}}
[[Category:Aerobatics|*]] [[Category:Aviation accidents and incidents at air shows|*]] [[Category:Lists of aviation accidents and incidents|Airshow]]

page.title: List of annual events in China

revision.text:
This is an incomplete list of notable [[treasure]]s that are currently lost or missing. {| class="wikitable sortable" style="width:100%;" |- ! width="200px" | Name ! width="80px | Existence ! width="60px" | Year lost ! class="unsortable" | Image ! class="unsortable" | Description |- | [[Menorah (Temple)|Menorah]] from the [[Second Temple]] | Confirmed | {{sort|191|191}} | [[File:Carrying off the Menorah from the Temple in Jerusalem depicted on a frieze on the Arch of Titus in the Forum Romanum.JPG|130px]]
Menorah from the Temple in Jerusalem depicted on a frieze on the Arch of Titus in Rome
