| The Menorah from the Second Temple in Jerusalem was [[Siege of Jerusalem (70 CE)|looted by the Romans in 70 AD]] and put on view in the [[Temple of Peace, Rome|Temple of Peace]] in [[Rome]]. The temple burned down in 191 after which the fate of the Menorah is uncertain. If it survived the fire, it could have been brought to [[Carthage]] by the [[Vandals]] after their [[Sack of Rome (455)|Sack of Rome]] in 455, as mentioned by [[Procopius]] in the 6th century. |- | [[Ganj-e Badavard]] | Legend | | | One of the eight treasures of the [[Sasanian Empire|Sasanian]] king [[Khosrow II]] |- | [[Heirloom Seal of the Realm]] | Confirmed | {{sort|960|circa 960}} |
—
| Imperial Seal of China created by Emperor [[Qin Shi Huang]], lost after the [[Five Dynasties and Ten Kingdoms period]]. |- | [[Egill Skallagrímsson]]'s silver | Legend | {{sort|990|circa 990-995|}} |
—
| A large quantity of silver coinage, allegedly buried near [[Mosfellsbær]], Iceland, when Egill was in his eighties. |- | [[Kusanagi]] | Legend | {{sort|1185|1185}} | [[File:三神器.png|130px]]
Artist's depiction
| A sword and one of the [[Three Sacred Treasures of Japan]] that legitimize the rule of [[Emperor of Japan|the Emperor]]. Lost at sea in the [[Battle of Dan-no-ura]] in the [[Genpei War]].{{Cite book |last=McCullough |first=Helen Craig |title =The Tale of the Heike |year=1988 |place= Stanford |publisher= Stanford University Press |isbn=0-8047-1418-5}} Current government claims possession, but has not permitted outside verification. |- | [[The Wash#King John.27s losing the Crown Jewels|Crown Jewels of England]] | Legend | {{sort|1216|1216}} |
—
| Baggage train of [[John, King of England|King John ("John Lackland")]], lost in [[The Wash]] during the [[First Barons' War]]. |- | [[Llywelyn's coronet]] | Legend | {{sort|1303|1303}} |
—
| The coronet of [[Llywelyn ap Gruffudd]], the last king of [[Wales]], it was seized along with other holy artifacts at the end of the [[Conquest of Wales by Edward I]], in 1284, was taken to London, and kept with the crown jewels in [[Westminster Abbey]] until they were stolen in 1303. It was not present in the inventory taken during the destruction of the crown jewels by [[Oliver Cromwell]] in 1649, and remains unaccounted for. |- | [[La Noche Triste|La Noche Triste treasure]] | Legend | {{sort|1520|1520}} |
—
| Massive amount of gold and silver [[bullion]] looted from the Treasure House of [[Moctezuma II]]. Occurred during the [[Spanish conquest of the Aztec Empire]].{{Cite book |last=Prescott |first=William H. | authorlink = William H. Prescott|title=History of the Conquest of Mexico |isbn=0-375-75803-8}} |- | Lost Inca gold | Legend | {{sort|1533|circa 1533}} |
—
| Originally intended as part of the ransom of [[Sapa Inca|Inca Emperor]] [[Atahualpa]] it would have been hidden once it became known that the Spanish had killed him.{{Cite web |last=James |first=Owen |title=Lost Inca Gold |url=http://www.nationalgeographic.com/archaeology-and-history/archaeology/lost-inca-gold/ |website=National Geographic}} |- | [[Amaro Rodríguez Felipe|Treasure of Amaro Pargo]] | Unidentified | 1678-1747 | [[File:Amaro Pargo.jpg|130px]]
Portrait of Amaro Pargo located on the canvas of the "Christ of Humility and Patience" of the Shrine of Our Lady of El Rosario in Machado ([[Tenerife]]).
| The treasure would be composed of "carved silver, gold jewelry, pearls and stones of value, Chinese porcelain, rich fabrics, paintings and perhaps 500,000 pesos".{{Cite news| last = Sánchez| first = Almudena| title = La ruta del pirata Amaro| work = Canarias7| location = Las Palmas de Gran Canaria| accessdate = 17 July 2016| url = http://www.canarias7.es/ocio/mochila/mochila.cfm?id=9| archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20160115082353/http://www.canarias7.es/ocio/mochila/mochila.cfm?id=9| archivedate = 15 January 2016}} The stories about this treasure are varied, some place it in the environment of the [[Roques de Anaga]], while others place it in the zone of [[Punta del Hidalgo]] and the cave of San Mateo, northeast of [[Tenerife]]. At present, said treasure has not been found nor identified. |- | [[Scepter of Dagobert]] | Confirmed | {{sort|1795|1795}} |[[File:Sceptre de Dagobert.jpg|60px]]
planche in: ''Dom Bernard de Montfaucon, Les monuments de la monarchie françoise''., Paris, 1729
| Originally part of the French Regalia, sometimes considered its oldest part, dating from the 7th century, it was stored in the treasure of the [[Basilica of Saint-Denis]] (also known as Basilique royale de Saint-Denis) until 1795, when it disappeared, probably stolen. |- | [[Oak Island mystery|Oak Island money pit]] | Confimed in Season 6 in the curse of oak island2018 | {{sort|1795|1795}} |
—
| A possible treasure trove located in a large hole on an island off the coast of [[Nova Scotia]], Canada.{{cite web|url=http://www.gadsdentimes.com/article/20140119/NEWS/140119844|title=DAVID MURDOCK: Oak Island's Money Pit|work=GadsdenTimes.com}}{{cite web|url=http://www.slate.com/blogs/atlas_obscura/2014/05/12/oak_island_money_pit_has_drawn_treasure_seekers_for_centuries.html|title=Oak Island Money Pit has drawn treasure seekers for centuries|work=Slate Magazine}} |- | [[Palmyra atoll#Esperanza treasure|Treasure of the ''Esperanza'']] | Reported | {{sort|1816|1816}} |
—
| 1.5 million gold pesos and an equal value in silver [[Pre-Columbian era|precolumbian]] art looted from the [[Viceroyalty of Peru]], shipped on the ''Esperanza,'' taken and buried by pirates shipwrecked on [[Palmyra Atoll]].{{cite news |url=http://palmyraarchive.org/items/show/75|last=Connor|first=Martin|date=April 14, 1923|title=Priceless Treasures of the Incas May Be Buried on Island in Palmyras|work=Honolulu Star-Bulletin|location=Honolulu|page=1|access-date=August 14, 2017}} |- | [[Treasure of Lima]] | Legend | {{sort|1820|1820}} |
—
| Gold, silver and jewellery stolen from the Spanish in 1820. The treasure is thought to be buried on [[Cocos Island]] in Costa Rica and it is estimated to be worth £160 million. |- | [[Confederate gold]] | Legend | {{sort|1865|circa 1865}} |
—
| Gold. Lost after the [[American Civil War]]. |- | [[:ja:徳川埋蔵金|Tokugawa's buried treasure]] | Legend | {{sort|1868|circa 1868}} |
—
| A legendary treasure allegedly buried in [[Mount Akagi]] by the [[Tokugawa shogunate]] (disputed). |- | [[Kruger Millions]] | Legend | {{sort|1902|1902}} |
—
| Millions of gold pounds presumed to have been produced by the Boer forces in the South African veld under order of President [[Paul Kruger]]. The money was believed to fund the purchase of weapons for the Boer Commandos. The funds went missing. Believed to have been buried or hidden somewhere in South Africa or taken by Kruger to Switzerland. |- | [[Irish Crown Jewels|Crown Jewels of Ireland]] | Confirmed | {{sort|1907|1907}} | [[File:Irishcrownjewels.jpg|130px]]
The Crown Jewels
| Heavily jewelled insignia of the [[Order of St. Patrick|Most Illustrious Order of St Patrick]]. Stolen from [[Dublin Castle]] in 1907. |- | [[RMS Republic (1903)|The Tsar's Treasure]] | Legend - Partially Confirmed | {{sort|1909|1909}} |
—
| $3 million in newly minted American [[double eagle]] coins destined to the Russian [[Baltic Fleet]], an $800,000 US Government shipment in mixed coin to the [[United States Fleet Forces Command|American Atlantic Fleet]], and the confirmed loss of $500,000 in passenger effects (all 1909 values) were lost when the [[RMS Republic (1903)|RMS Republic]] foundered off the coast of New England as a result of a collision. |- | [[Florentine Diamond]] | Confirmed | {{sort|1918|1918}} | [[File:Florentine Diamond copy.jpg|120px]]
Copy of the diamond
| Lost yellow diamond with Indian origin. |- | [[Fabergé egg|Lost Imperial Fabergé eggs]] | Confirmed | {{sort|1922|1922 or later}} | [[File:Alexander Egg.jpg|130px]]
The Alexander III Commemorative egg
| Seven eggs in the Imperial series are missing:[http://wintraecken.nl/mieks/faberge/eggs/missing.html Website by Annemiek Wintraecken: Missing Fabergé Eggs] * 1886 – [[Hen with Sapphire Pendant|The Hen with Sapphire Pendant egg]] * 1888 – [[Cherub with Chariot Egg|The Cherub with Chariot egg]] * 1889 – [[Nécessaire Egg|The Nécessaire egg]] * 1897 – [[Mauve (Fabergé egg)|The Mauve egg]] * 1902 – [[Empire Nephrite (Fabergé egg)|The Empire Nephrite egg]] * 1903 – [[Royal Danish (Fabergé egg)|The Royal Danish egg]] * 1909 – [[Alexander III Commemorative (Fabergé egg)|The Alexander III Commemorative egg]] |- | ''[[The Just Judges]]'' | Confirmed | {{sort|1934|1934}} | [[File:Ghent Altarpiece E - Just Judges by Vanderveken.jpg|100px]]
Replica
| Lower left panel of the [[Ghent Altarpiece|Adoration of the Mystic Lamb]], which was displayed at the [[Saint Bavo Cathedral]] in [[Ghent, Belgium]], was stolen during the night of 10 April 1934. |- | [[Royal Casket]] | Confirmed | {{sort|1939|1939}} | [[File:Royal Casket.JPG|130px]]
The Royal Casket
| Memorial containing 73 precious relics{{cite web |author =Barbara Kobielska |url =http://www.worldcat.org/issn/1428-6467|title=Cenne, Bezcenne, Utracone (Valuable, Priceless, Lost) |work =|publisher=Pagina |pages= |page= |date=|accessdate=26 November 2009|language=pl}} that had once belonged to [[Polish monarchs|Polish royalty]]. Looted during World War II. |- | ''[[Peking Man]]'' | Confirmed | {{sort|1941|1941–1945}} | [[File:Peking Man Skull (replica) presented at Paleozoological Museum of China.jpg|130px]]
Replica
| Fossil remains of ''Homo erectus pekinensis''; dated ~500,000 years old. Lost during World War II in China in 1941 or may have been on the ''[[MV Awa Maru (1943)|Awa Maru]]'' when it sank in 1945.{{cite web | url=http://www.nsa.gov/public/pdf/sinkingawa_maru.pdf |format=PDF| title=Sinking and salvage of the ''Awa Maru''}} |- | [[Amber Room]] | Confirmed | {{sort|1945|circa 1945}} | [[File:Bernsteinzimmer02.jpg|130px]]
Reconstruction
| Removed from [[Catherine Palace]], [[Saint Petersburg]], by Germans during World War II and transported to Germany. Estimated (adjusted) value: $142 million. Reconstructed in 2003. |- | [[Yamashita's gold]] | Legend | {{sort|1945|circa 1945}} |
—
| War loot stolen by Japanese and hidden in the Philippines. Alleged. Named for General [[Tomoyuki Yamashita]]. |- | [[MV Awa Maru (1943)|''Awa Maru'' treasure]] | Legend | {{sort|1945|1945}} |
—
| Gold, platinum, and diamonds worth more than $5 billion. Alleged. It was lost when the Japanese ship ''[[MV Awa Maru (1942)|Awa Maru]]'' was hit by a torpedo and sank in April 1945. |- | [[Nazi gold train]] | Legend | {{sort|1945|1945}} |
—
|A train laden with gold and other treasures hidden by the Nazi Germans in a tunnel near [[Wałbrzych]], Poland. |- | [[Honjo Masamune|Honjō Masamune]] | Confirmed | {{sort|1945|1945}} |
—
| The Honjō Masamune, a legendary [[samurai]] sword, created by the master swordmaker [[Masamune|Gorō Masamune]] between 1288 and 1328 AD. The sword was passed down over the centuries from [[Shōgun]] to Shōgun, and is considered a priceless Japanese cultural artifact. |- | [[Patiala Necklace]] | Confirmed | {{sort|1948|circa 1948}} | [[File:Bhupendra Singh Patiala.jpg|130px]]
The Patiala Necklace
| A necklace containing 2,930 diamonds including the world's seventh largest diamond, the 428 carat "De Beers". Some diamonds later recovered. Made by the [[Cartier S.A.|House of Cartier]] in 1928 for [[Bhupinder Singh of Patiala]], then ruling [[Maharaja]] of [[Patiala]]. |- | [[Chelengk|Nelson's Chelengk]] | Confirmed | {{sort|1951|1951}} | [[File:HoratioNelson1.jpg|130px]]
Nelson with the Chelengk in his hat
| A medal made of diamonds given to Admiral [[Horatio Nelson, 1st Viscount Nelson|Horatio Nelson]] for his naval service. Placed in the [[National Maritime Museum]] in London in 1929 and stolen in 1951. |- | [[Tucker's Cross]] | Confirmed | {{sort|1975|1975}} |
—
| Emerald-studded gold cross, discovered in a shipwreck in 1955 and stolen from a museum in Bermuda in 1959. |- | [[Lufthansa heist]] | Confirmed | {{sort|1978|1978}} |
—
| Cash and jewels from a robbery at Lufthansa's cargo terminal at [[John F. Kennedy International Airport]] in December 1978. With a value of about $5 million, it was the largest cash robbery in the United States at the time. |- | [[Brink's-Mat robbery]] | Confirmed | {{sort|1983|1983}} |
—
| Gold bullion, diamonds, and cash valued at £26 million (worth approximately £79 million in 2015) |- | [[Antwerp Diamond Heist|Antwerp Diamond heist]] | Confirmed | {{sort|2003|2003}} |
—
| Diamonds, gold and other jewels worth $189 million. Dubbed the "heist of the century". |- | [[Graff Diamonds robbery]] | Confirmed | {{sort|2009|2009}} |
—
| 43 items of jewellery, stolen in London on 6 August 2009. Valued at nearly £40 million. |- | [[Ivory Coast Crown Jewels]] | Confirmed | {{sort|2011|2011}} |
—
| Gold pendants, necklaces and bracelets worth $6 million. |- | [[Brussels Airport diamond heist]] | Confirmed | {{sort|2013|2013}} |
—
| Diamonds stolen from airplane at Brussels Airport valued at $50 million. |- | [[Hatton Garden safe deposit burglary]] | Confirmed | {{sort|2015|2015}} |
—
| Safe deposit facility burgled in London, total stolen could have been up to £200M |- | Funeral regalia of King [[Charles IX of Sweden]] and Queen [[Christina of Holstein-Gottorp]] | Confirmed | {{sort|2018|2018}} | [[File:Strängnäs Domkyrka - KMB - 16000200105370.jpg|130px]]
Queen Christina's crown
[[File:Strängnäs Domkyrka - KMB - 16000200105373.jpg|130px]]
King Charles IX's crown
[[File:Strängnäs Domkyrka - KMB - 16000200105378.jpg|130px]]
Orb
| Two crowns and an orb stolen from [[Strängnäs Cathedral]]. Considered priceless artefacts |} * {{Expand list|date=June 2016}} ==See also== {{div col|colwidth=30em}} * [[Art theft and looting during World War II]] * [[Looted art]] * [[Lost artworks]] * [[Lost film]] * [[List of lost television broadcasts]] * [[Lost history]] * [[Lost work]] * [[Nazi gold]] * [[Nazi plunder]] {{div col end}} ==References== {{reflist|30em|refs= {{cite news |title=British expedition to Pacific 'treasure island' where pirates buried their plunder |first=Jasper |last=Copping |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/centralamericaandthecaribbean/costarica/9450737/British-expedition-to-Pacific-treasure-island-where-pirates-buried-their-plunder.html# |newspaper=The Daily Telegraph |date=5 August 2012 |accessdate=16 October 2012}} {{cite news |title=A Brief History of the Amber Room |first=Jess |last=Blumberg |url=http://www.smithsonianmag.com/history-archaeology/world-history/brief_amber.html |newspaper=Smithsonian |date=1 August 2007 |accessdate=15 October 2012}} {{cite news |title=Bio of Bermuda Teddy Tucker|url=http://bernews.com/bermuda-profiles/teddy-tucker/ |newspaper=BerNews |accessdate=4 November 2013}} {{cite book |title=Gold Warriors: America's Secret Recovery of Yamashita's Gold |last1=Seagrave |first1=Sterling |last2=Seagrave |first2=Peggy |year=2003 |publisher=Verso |isbn=9781859845424 |page=203 |url=https://books.google.com/?id=Qp55OCtxugEC&pg=PA203&lpg=PA203&dq=name+of+Awa+maru}} {{cite news |title=Henry Hill, Mobster and Movie Inspiration, Dies at 69 |first=Margalit |last=Fox |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2012/06/14/nyregion/henry-hill-mobster-of-goodfellas-dies-at-69.html |newspaper=The New York Times |date=13 June 2012 |accessdate=16 October 2012}} {{cite news |title=After years spent dodging bullets and avoiding sleeping with the fishes, Henry Hill - the real-life mafia turncoat immortalized in the film Goodfellas - dies naturally aged 69 |first=David |last=Gardner |url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-2158594/Henry-Hill-dead-Real-life-mafia-man-immortalized-film-Goodfellas-dies-69.html |newspaper=Mail Online |date=13 June 2012 |accessdate=16 October 2012}} {{cite news |title=Stolen Jewels, Art and Cash: World's Biggest Heists |first=Russell|last=Goldman |url=http://abcnews.go.com/Business/story?id=8314545 |newspaper=ABC News |date=13 August 2009 |accessdate=15 October 2012}} {{cite news |title=Graff Diamonds £40 million jewellery robbery is Britain's biggest gem heist |first=Richard |last=Edwards |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/6010698/Graff-Diamonds-40-million-jewellery-robbery-is-Britains-biggest-gem-heist.html |newspaper=The Daily Telegraph |date=11 August 2009 |accessdate=15 October 2012}} {{cite news |title=Thief! Ivory Coast's Crown Jewels Stolen |first=Daniel |last=Tovrov |url=http://www.ibtimes.com/thief-ivory-coasts-crown-jewels-stolen-298179 |newspaper=International Business Times |date=13 July 2011 |accessdate=15 October 2012}} {{cite web|last=Chrisafis|first=Angelique| work = [[The Guardian]]| title=Diamond heist at Brussels airport nets gang up to £30m in gems |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2013/feb/19/diamond-robbery-brussels-airport-plane|date=19 February 2013|accessdate=19 February 2013}} {{cite news|title=Swedish crown jewels: Speedboat thieves steal priceless treasures|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-45028732|publisher=BBC News|date=1 August 2018|accessdate=1 August 2018}} }} ==External links== * [http://thelongestlistofthelongeststuffatthelongestdomainnameatlonglast.com/treasures.html List of Lost Treasures] {{Treasure}} {{Use dmy dates|date=October 2012}} [[Category:Lost objects|Treasure]] [[Category:Treasure]] [[Category:Lists of unexplained disappearances|Treasure]]

This articles lists times that items were renamed due to political motivations. Such renamings have generally occurred during conflicts; for example, [[World War I]] gave rise to anti-German sentiment among [[Allies of World War I|Allied]] nations, leading to disassociation with German names.[[File:Liberty Steak Cartoon.JPG|thumb|250px|An early political cartoon lampooning the name change of hamburger meat during World War I.]]
== Asia == *Muslim World: Israel is called by some commentators "[[Zionist entity|The Zionist Entity]]" as a pejorative. *[[Iran]]: During the [[Jyllands-Posten Muhammad cartoons controversy]] in 2006, several Iranian groups advocated changing the name of [[Danish pastry]] to "Roses of the Prophet Muhammad".<ref>{{cite news | url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/middle_east/4724656.stm | title = Iranians rename Danish pastries | work = [[BBC]] |accessdate = 2008-03-20 | date=2006-02-17}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url = http://english.aljazeera.net/news/archive/archive?ArchiveId=18788 | date=2006-03-02| publisher=[[Al Jazeera]] | title = Iran targets Danish pastries | work = [[Associated Press]] |accessdate = 2008-03-20 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20061208031400/http://english.aljazeera.net/news/archive/archive?ArchiveId=18788 |archivedate = 2006-12-08}}</ref> *[[Philippines]]: On September 12, 2012, the Philippine President [[Benigno Aquino III]] signed Administrative Order No. 29 renaming parts of the [[South China Sea]], "West Philippine Sea". The renamed portions of the sea are within the [[Exclusive Economic Zone]] of the Philippines and contains the islands of [[Spratlys]] and [[Scarborough Shoal]] which [[South China Sea dispute|is disputed]] among five other countries.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Ubac|first1=Michael Lim|title=It’s official: Aquino signs order on West Philippine Sea|url=http://globalnation.inquirer.net/50012/its-official-aquino-signs-order-on-west-philippine-sea|publisher=Philippine Daily Inquirer|accessdate=10 July 2015|date=13 September 2012}}</ref>
== Oceania == *[[Australia]]: During [[World War I]], jam-filled buns known as Berliners were renamed [[Kitchener bun]]s, and a sausage product known as "Fritz" was renamed "[[Devon (sausage)|Devon]]" (or "luncheon meat").{{Citation needed|date=January 2013}} *[[New Zealand]]: In 1998, while the French government was testing nuclear weapons in the Pacific, French loaves were renamed Kiwi loaves in a number of supermarkets and bakeries.
== Europe == *[[Cyprus]]: Greek-Cypriots began to market [[Turkish Delight]] as Cyprus Delight after the [[Turkish invasion of Cyprus]].<ref>{{cite news| url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/europe/3753928.stm | work=BBC News | title=Cyprus villagers make giant sweet | date=2004-10-18}}</ref> *[[France]]: **[[French Revolution]]: the Committee of Public Safety went so far as to banish all words associated with royalty. A major example of their work was taking ''[[King (playing card)|Kings]]'' and ''[[Queen (playing card)|Queens]]'' out of playing cards and replacing them with Committee members. It lasted less than a year. It is commonly believed that this was also the time when Aces earnt their status as being both the highest card and the lowest card.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://irishherault.wordpress.com/2010/01/31/playing-cards-france-politics/|work=[[irishherault.wordpress.com]]|title=French playing cards and card stuff|date=2010-01-31|accessdate=2010-11-22|first=Irish|last=Hérault}}</ref> **World War I: coffee with whipped cream, previously known as ''Café Viennois'' (Vienna coffee), was renamed ''Café Liégeois'' (Coffee from [[Liège]]) due to the state of war with Austria-Hungary. This appellation is still in use today, mainly for ice-creams (''chocolat liégeois'' and ''café liegeois'').{{Citation needed|date=May 2009}} *[[Germany]]: In 1915, after [[Italy]] entered World War I, restaurants in [[Berlin]] stopped serving [[Salad|Italian salad]].{{Citation needed|date=May 2009}} *[[Greece]]: ''Ellinikos kafes'' 'Greek coffee' replaced ''Turkikos kafes'' '[[Turkish coffee]]' on Greek menus in the 1960s<ref>[[Turkish coffee#Greece]]</ref> and especially after the 1974 [[Turkish invasion of Cyprus|Cyprus crisis]].<ref>Robert Browning, ''Medieval and Modern Greek'', 1983. {{ISBN|0-521-29978-0}}. p. 16</ref> *[[Russia]]: **During World War I, [[Saint Petersburg]] was renamed 'Petrograd', amounting effectively to a translation of the name from German to Russian. **At a meeting on November 16, 2016 with the prime ministers of Armenia, Belarus, Kazakhstan, and Kyrgyzstan, Russia’s prime minister Dmitry Medvedev suggested that [[Caffè_Americano|Americano coffee]] should be renamed “Rusiano coffee". Also, in 2014, following Moscow’s annexation of Crimea, several cafes on the peninsula changed their menus to read “Russiano” and “Crimean,” in place of Americano coffee.<ref>https://themoscowtimes.com/news/russias-prime-minister-says-eurasia-should-call-it-rusiano-coffee-not-americano-56180</ref> *[[Spain]]: After the triumph of [[Francisco Franco]], ''filete imperial'' ("imperial beef") became a [[euphemism]] for ''filete ruso'' ("Russian beef"), "ensaladilla nacional" ("national salad") for "ensaladilla rusa" ([[Russian salad]]) and ''Caperucita Encarnada'' ("[[Little Red Riding Hood]]") for ''Caperucita Roja'' (which has the same meaning but loses its hypothetical connotations).{{Citation needed|date=May 2009}} *[[United Kingdom]]: **World War I: ***The [[German Shepherd]] was renamed the "Alsatian," and German biscuits were renamed [[Empire biscuit]]s due to strong anti-German sentiment. ***The members of the British royal house, a branch of the German [[House of Saxe-Coburg and Gotha]], severed ties with their German cousins following several bombing raids on England by the first long-range bomber, the [[Gotha G.IV]] starting in March, 1917. On July 17, 1917, King [[George V of the United Kingdom|George V]] changed the family's name to the [[House of Windsor]].
== North America ==
*[[Canada]]: **World War I: the Ontario city of [[Berlin to Kitchener name change|Berlin was renamed]] [[Kitchener, Ontario|Kitchener]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.collectionscanada.gc.ca/education/premiereguerre/05180204/0518020404_e.html |title=Name - If some things never change, when did they begin? |date=2004-02-04 |accessdate=2008-02-20 |work=[[Library and Archives Canada]] |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080517152007/http://www.collectionscanada.gc.ca/education/premiereguerre/05180204/0518020404_e.html |archivedate=2008-05-17 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> **[[World War II]], the [[Government of Ontario]] unsuccessfully attempted to change the name of [[Swastika, Ontario]], to Winston, Ontario, to disassociate the relation with [[Nazism]]. Locals named their community before the Nazis adopted the [[Swastika]] symbol. * [[United States]]: **World War I: The [[German Spitz]] was renamed the [[American Eskimo Dog]] **[[Great Depression]]: In 1928, during the last months of the [[Calvin Coolidge]] administration, Congress approved the construction of a [[dam]] on the [[Colorado River]] southeast of [[Las Vegas]], [[Nevada]]. The press referred to it as "Boulder Dam" as a reference to the construction site, Boulder Canyon. While in Nevada in 1930, [[United States Secretary of the Interior|Secretary of the Interior]] [[Ray Lyman Wilbur]] referred to the project as "[[Hoover Dam]]", a reference to [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican]] [[President of the United States|President]] [[Herbert Hoover]]. Following Hoover's defeat by [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democrat]] [[Franklin D. Roosevelt]], Wilbur's successor, [[Harold L. Ickes]], declared in 1933 that the dam should be called "Boulder Dam". In 1947, the Republican-controlled Congress changed the name back to "Hoover Dam". **[[War on Terror]]: During the [[2003 invasion of Iraq]], [[freedom fries]] was a short-lived political euphemism for [[French fries]], used by some to express their disapproval of the French opposition to the invasion.<ref name=autogenerated1>{{cite web | url = http://www.digitalhistory.uh.edu/database/article_display.cfm?HHID=531 | title = Over Here: World War I on the Home Front | work = Digital History | accessdate = 2006-07-12 | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20060813211700/http://www.digitalhistory.uh.edu/database/article_display.cfm?HHID=531 | archivedate = 2006-08-13 | df = }}</ref> In response to the French government's opposition to the prospective invasion of Iraq in 2003, the Republican Chairman on the Committee of House Administration renamed French fries "Freedom Fries," and the change was originally supported and followed by some restaurants. The term has since reverted to the original.
==See also== * [[Geographical renaming]]
==Notes== <references/>
[[Category:Figures of speech]] [[Category:Censorship]] [[Category:Events relating to freedom of expression]] [[Category:Self-censorship]] [[Category:Political correctness]] [[Category:Euphemisms]]

revision.comment: Updated Dover Steam Show and its citation
revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=March 2014}} A '''steam fair''' or (steam rally) is a regular organised gathering of historic [[steam engine|steam-powered]] vehicles and machinery, open to the public. Typical exhibits include: [[traction engine]]s, [[steam roller]]s, [[steam wagon]]s, and [[steam car]]s. Often, the scope is widened to include other historic exhibits such as [[stationary engine]]s, internal-combustion -powered road transport, agricultural and construction vehicles, working horses, woodcraft and the like.
A typical steam fair consists of: * A parade ring or track in which vehicles may be demonstrated * Trade and craft stalls related to the exhibits * Areas where vehicles may be examined more closely and the public may talk to owners and operators * Entertainment areas (often, a beer tent) with food, drink, and evening music * A fairground area may also be included in the event
The following is a geographic list of these gatherings, some of which are referred to as ''rallies'' or as ''festivals''. The list does not include static steam museums unless they host a particular event that falls into the classification.
In addition there are some travelling shows powered by steam. Where these are referred to as ''steam fairs'' they are included in the list.
<!-- In due course it is likely that each region or nation may have its own list. In the meantime please add carefully in alphabetical order creating new headings for new nations or regions, and ideally including a reference to the individual event. --> {{Dynamic list}}
==Australia== *[[Melbourne Steam Traction Engine Club#Annual rally|Scoresby Steamfest]] * Lake Goldsmith steam rally (Twice yearly) *[[Hunter Valley Steamfest]]
==Canada== *[[Steam Era|Steam-Era]]<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.steam-era.com |title=Steam-Era |accessdate=2008-11-03 |publisher=[[Ontario Steam & Antique Preservers Association]]}}</ref> *[[Threshermen's Reunion]] – ''([[Austin, Manitoba]])'' [[Georgian Bay Steam Show]]_"[[Cookstown, Ontario
==Ireland== *[[Eyrecourt]] *[[Innishannon Steam and Vintage Rally]] – ''(1998- )'' *[[Stradbally#Steam rally|Stradbally - Irish National Steam Rally]] – ''(1965- )''<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.irishsteam.ie/Welcome.html |title=National Steam Rally back on track |publisher=[[Irish Steam Preservation Society]] |accessdate=2008-11-03 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090309025308/http://www.irishsteam.ie/Welcome.html |archivedate=9 March 2009 }}</ref> *[[Upton Steam Rally]] – ''( -1997)''
==Netherlands== *[[Dordt in Stoom]], Dordrecht - ''(1985- )'' bi-annual large event in and around the historic harbour district with steam powered ships, trains, river boats and other engines.<ref>[http://www.dordtinstoom.nl/home_english.html Dordt in Stoom] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100526101917/http://www.dordtinstoom.nl/home_english.html |date=26 May 2010 }}</ref>
==Poland== [[File:Steam Locomotives Parade 2012 - distant view (Wolsztyn, Poland).jpg|thumb|right|Steam locomotive parade in Wolsztyn]] *[[Wolsztyn]] – ''(1993- )'' annual steam locomotive parade held the last weekend of April near a historic roundhouse *[[Chabówka]] – ''(2005- )'' "Parowozjada" - steam locomotive parade held the last weekend of August in a railway museum near the railway station
==United Kingdom== [[File:GDSF (2007) Shomans Engines at night.JPG|thumb|right|[[Great Dorset Steam Fair]]: night-time view of the line-up of 40+ [[showman's engine]]s, in the vintage fairground section]]
===Static events=== *1000 Engine Rally, [[Chelford]], [[Cheshire]], staged in June (1985 - )<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.1000engines.co.uk1000/ |title=1000 Engine Rally Homepage}}</ref> * [http://abbeyhillrally.co.uk Abbey Hill Steam Rally [[Yeovil]], [[Somerset]] (1980 -) (Next Rally May Day Bank Holiday Weekend - Friday 2–5 May 2014)] *[[Astle Park]] Traction Engine Rally, Chelford, Cheshire, staged in August <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.number1events.com/astle_park_traction_engine_rally.htm |title=Astle Park Traction Engine Rally |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100818004752/http://www.number1events.com/astle_park_traction_engine_rally.htm |archivedate=18 August 2010 }}</ref> *[[Barton Gate Charity Steam Rally]] - ''(1995- )''<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.doveridgesteam.co.uk/|title=Barton Gate Charity Steam Rally|accessdate=15 June 2010}}</ref> * [http://www.lsvc.org Boconnoc Steam Fair [[Cornwall]] - ''(1998- )'']<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.lsvc.org/|title=Boconnoc Steam Fair|accessdate=16 January 2015}}</ref> *[[Burtonwood airfield]], Lancashire ''(1970s—1980s)'' *[[Cadeby, Leicestershire#Cadeby Steam & Country Fayre|Cadeby Steam & Country Fayre]] – ''44 years (1964-2008)'' <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mallorypark.co.uk/News/PressReleaseArchive2008/CadebySteamRallyatMalloryPark/tabid/557/Default.aspx |title=Cadeby Steam Rally at Mallory Park |accessdate=2008-11-03 |publisher=[[Mallory Park]] |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081010193222/http://www.mallorypark.co.uk/News/PressReleaseArchive2008/CadebySteamRallyatMalloryPark/tabid/557/Default.aspx |archivedate=10 October 2008 }}</ref><ref>[http://www.cadebysteam.co.uk/index.html Cadeby Steam & Country Fayre] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080916005238/http://www.cadebysteam.co.uk/index.html |date=16 September 2008 }}</ref> *[[Castle Combe Circuit|Castle Combe]], Wiltshire, held in May *[[Cambridgeshire Steam Rally, Swavesey]] – ''(2009- )'' *[[Chickerell Steam and Vintage Show]] - ''(2004-)''<ref>[http://theportlandsteamshow.co.uk]</ref> *[[Cromford Steam Rally]] ''38 years (as of 2008))''<ref>[http://www.cromford-steam.co.uk Cromford steam Rally] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080724085724/http://www.cromford-steam.co.uk/ |date=24 July 2008 }}</ref> *[[Great Dorset Steam Fair]] – ''(1968- )'' *[[Grand Henham Steam Rally]] - ''(1974- )'' *[[Haddenham, Cambridgeshire|Haddenham Steam Rally and Heavy Horse Show]] - ''(1974- )'' <ref>[http://www.haddenhamsteamrally.co.uk Haddenham Steam Rally]</ref> *[[Holcot Steam Rally & Country Fair]] ''11th year (2008)''<ref>Old Glory Events Guide pt2, 2008</ref> *[[Hollowell Steam Rally and Heavy Horse Show]] – ''(1986- )''<ref>[http://www.hollowellsteam.com Hollowell Steam Rally ]</ref> *[[Hollycombe Steam Collection]] - ''(1971-)''<ref>[http://www.hollycombe.co.uk Hollycombe Steam Collection]</ref> *Island Steam Show, held at the [[Isle of Wight Steam Railway]] - ''(1975-)''<ref>[http://www.iwsteamrailway.co.uk/events/the-40th-island-steam-show.aspx]</ref> *[[Kettering Vintage Rally & Steam Fayre]] - ''(2000- )''<ref>[http://www.kettering-vintage-rally.co.uk Kettering Vintage rally]</ref> *[[Knowl Hill, Berkshire#Knowl Hill Steam Rally|Knowl Hill Steam Rally]] – ''( -2004)'' *[[Lincolnshire Steam and Vintage Rally]] 23rd year (2008) <ref>Old Glory Events guide, 2008</ref> *[[Cadeby, Leicestershire#Cadeby Steam & Country Fayre|Market Bosworth Steam Rally]] *[[Netley Marsh Steam and Craft Fair]] - ''(1971- )''<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.netleymarshsteamandcraftshow.org/the_charity.htm |title=Netley Marsh Steam and Craft Show, near Southampton, Hants |publisher=Netleymarshsteamandcraftshow.org |date=2013-09-17 |accessdate=2014-02-14}}</ref> *[[Northleach Steam & Vintage Show]] - ''(c1950s - )''<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.northleachsteamshow.co.uk |title=Northleach Steam and Vintage Show, Northleach, Gloucestershire |publisher=Northleachsteamshow.co.uk |date=2014-12-16 |accessdate=2014-12-16}}</ref> * [http://mosterton.isgreat.org Mosterton Summer Show (Latest Rally - 2 & 3 July 2011)] *[[Ringmer Steam & Country Show]] – ''(2003- )<ref>[http://www.ringmershow.co.uk Ringmer Steam & Country Show]</ref> [[Ringmer]], [[East Sussex]]'' *[[Rudgwick Steam & Country Show]] – ''(1987- )<ref>[http://www.rudgwicksteamshow.co.uk Rudgwick Steam & Country Show]</ref> [[Rudgwick]], [[West Sussex]]'' *[[Rushmoor Steam Rally]] – ''( - c1991)<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.basingstoke-canal.org.uk/bcnews157.htm |title=The Basingstoke Canal (Sales Stand Venues 1991) |date=June 1991 |accessdate=2008-11-03 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080910024944/http://www.basingstoke-canal.org.uk/bcnews157.htm |archivedate=10 September 2008 }}</ref> Rushmoor Arena, [[Aldershot]], [[Hampshire]]'' *[https://web.archive.org/web/20110814023801/http://www.somersetspectacular.co.uk/steam.htm Somerset Steam Spectacular - 52nd year. mid July (2011)] *[http://www.scortonsteam.co.uk Scorton Steam - held on third weekend in June (2005-) ] * [http://www.shrewsburysteamrally.co.uk Shrewsbury Steam Rally, [[Shropshire]] (1962 -) Late August Bank Holiday Sunday and Monday (Organised by The County of Salop Steam Engine Society) ] *[[Tavistock Steam Fair]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.therobeytrust.co.uk/|title=The Robey Trust|accessdate=15 June 2010|quote=...the Tavistock Steam Fair, normally takes place on the Sunday of the first weekend of June every year.}}</ref> *[[Torbay Steam Fair]] – ''(1987- )''<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.torbaysteamfair.com |title=Torbay Steam Fair |accessdate=2008-11-03}}</ref> *[[Wiston Steam Rally]] – ''(2011- )<ref>{{cite web |url=| title =Wiston Steam Rally}}</ref> [[West Sussex]]''
===Travelling shows=== *[[Carter's Steam Fair]] – ''(1976- )'' A [[travelling funfair]] that travels throughout [[London]] and the home counties from [[Easter]] to [[Bonfire Night]]. <ref>{{Cite web|title = All the fun of the steam powered fair|url = http://www.readersdigest.co.uk/entertainment/out-about/all-fun-steam-powered-fair|website = www.readersdigest.co.uk|accessdate = 2015-12-07}}</ref>
==United States== [[File:MW Old Threshers Reunion 2010.JPG|thumb|Steam tractor lineup at the 2010 [[Old Thresher's Reunion]].]] *[[Antique Gas & Steam Engine Museum]] - bi-annual show in Vista, California *[[Antique Powerland]], Brooks Oregon. Annual Steam-Up<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.antiquepowerland.com/info/annual.html |title=Annual Steam-up |publisher=Antique Powerland |accessdate=2009-02-15}}</ref> *[[Antique Power and Steam Show]] - Large annual show taking place in the Lake County Fairgrounds in Indiana. *[http://www.badgersteamandgas.com/Club_events.htm Badger Steam and Gas Show] - Annual show hosted by Badger Steam and Gas Engine Club near Baraboo, WI * The Buckley Old Engine Show in Buckley Michigan<ref>[http://www.buckleyoldengineshow.org/ The Buckley Old Engine Show] Retrieved 2010-07-27</ref> *K&O Steam and Gas Engine Show, Windfield Kansas. *[[Central North Dakota Steam Thresher's Reunion]] – ''(1958- )''<ref>{{cite web |url=http://newrockfordnd.govoffice2.com/index.asp?Type=B_BASIC&SEC={5AF9FD69-1983-4678-8791-D5A52C20BE07} |title=Central North Dakota Steam Thresher's Reunion |publisher=[[City of New Rockford]], [[North Dakota]]| accessdate=2008-11-03}}</ref> *The Dover Steam Show – ''(1964- )'' Annual show hosted by Tuscarawas Valley Pioneer Power Association<ref>{{cite web |url=http://doversteamshow.com/index.html |title=The Dover Steam Show |publisher=Tuscarawas Valley Pioneer Power Association |accessdate=2018-09-18}}</ref> *[[Great Steamboat Race]] - ''(1963- )'' annual round trip race from Louisville, Kentucky to Jeffersonville, Indiana and back between steamboats on the Ohio River<ref>[http://www.kdf.org/events/eventviewer.asp?id=129 ] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081111014215/http://www.kdf.org/events/eventviewer.asp?id=129 |date=11 November 2008 }}</ref> *[[Old Thresher's Reunion]] - ''(1960- )'' Labor Day weekend, [[Mount Pleasant, Iowa]]. *[[National Threshers Association]] ''(1944- )'' annual reunion/show held in Wauseon, Ohio, last full weekend of June<ref>[http://www.nationalthreshers.com/default.htm/ National Threshers Association] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080709033549/http://www.nationalthreshers.com/default.htm |date=9 July 2008 }}</ref> *[http://nwoama.com/nwoama1/ Northwest Ohio Antique Machinery Association Antique Machinery Show] - Findlay, OH *[http://www.nowthenthreshing.com/node/2/ Nowthen Threshing Show] - Annual show held on the third full weekend (Friday-Sunday) in August, in [[Nowthen, Minnesota]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nowthenthreshing.com/|title=Nowthen Historical Power Association, Inc.}}</ref>. *[[Pageant of Steam]] - ''(1960- )'' annual fair held in [[Canandaigua (city), New York|Canandaigua, New York]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.pageantofsteam.org/|title=New York Steam Engine Association: Pageant of Steam|accessdate=2008-11-09}}</ref> *[http://www.oklahomathreshers.org/ Pawnee Steam and Gas Engine Show] - held first full weekend in May in Pawnee, OK *[[Pioneer Engineers Club]] of Rushville, IN - yearly show in Rushville, IN<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.pioneerengineers.com |title=Pioneer Engineers Club of Indiana, Inc |publisher=Pioneerengineers.com |date= |accessdate=2014-02-14}}</ref> *[[Rock River Thresheree]] [[Edgerton, Wisconsin]] – ''(1955- )'' <ref>[http://www.thresheree.org/Rock River Thresheree, Inc.]{{dead link|date=January 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> *[[Rough and Tumble Engineers Historical Association]] Kinzers, Pennsylvania<ref>http://www.roughandtumble.org</ref> * Shenandoah Valley Steam & Gas Engine Association, Berryville, VA "Pageant of Steam" held each year the last full weekend in July<ref>[http://www.svsgea.com/steam-shows.html]</ref> *[[Soule’ Live Steam Festival and Railfest]] annual event held the first weekend in November in Meridian, MS.<ref>[http://www.soulelivesteam.com/ Soule’ Live Steam Festival and Railfest]</ref> *[[Southeast Old Threshers' Reunion]] annual event held July 1-July 5 in Denton, NC <ref>[http://dentonfarmpark.com/event/2015-southeast-old-threshers-reunion]</ref> *[[Steamstock: An Antiquarian Exposition]] in Point Richmond, CA is an annual event held in July in a former Ford motor factory, next to the Rosie the Riveter Museum.<ref>[http://www.steamstock.org/ Steamstock]</ref> *[[Tall Stacks]] - held every 3 or 4 years in Cincinnati, Ohio since 1988; is a fair for steam powered riverboats.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.tallstacks.com/ |title=Tall Stacks Music Arts & Heritage Festival |publisher=Tallstacks.com |date= |accessdate=2014-02-14}}</ref> *[http://tuckahoesteam.org/ Tuckahoe Steam & Gas Association near Easton, MD] - annual "Steam Show" ''(1973- )'' in early July.<ref>[http://www.tuckahoesteam.org/ Tuckahoe Steam & Gas Association]</ref> *[[Western Minnesota Steam Thresher's Reunion]] (WMSTR) Rollag, Minnesota<ref>[http://www.rollag.com Western Minnesota Steam Threshers Reunion]</ref> *[http://alexandersteamshow.com/ Western New York Gas & Steam Engine Association Annual Rally] - Alexander, NY *[[Cama Powerup Spring and Fall]] Kent, CT <ref>[http://www.ctamachinery.com Connecticut Antique Machinery Association (CAMA)]</ref> *[[Missouri River Valley Steam Engine Association Back to the Farm Reunion]] Boonevill, MO <ref>[http://www.mrvsea.com Missouri River Valley Steam Engine Association (MRVSEA]</ref> *[[Riverbend Steam and Gas Association]] Allendale, MI <ref>[http://www.riverbendsteamandgas.i8.com Riverbend Steam and Gas Association]</ref> *The Michigan Steam Engine and Threshers Club Reunion, Mason, MI.<ref name="Hook">{{cite news|last1=Hook|first1=Larry|title=Thousands flock to Mason for 54th annual Michigan Steam Engine & Threshers Club reunion|url=http://www.mlive.com/lansing-news/index.ssf/2012/07/thousands_flock_to_mason_for_5.html|accessdate=2 October 2017|work=MLive.com}}</ref>
==Notes== {{reflist|30em}}
==See also== {{Portal|Trains}}
*[[Live steam]] *[[Hollycombe Steam Collection]] – ''essentially a steam fair, but in the form of a museum'' *[[Thursford Collection]] – ''steam museum featuring traction engines''
==External links== *[http://www.steamfair.co.uk List of UK Steam Fairs] *[http://www.steam-up.co.uk/ UK Traction engine rallies] *[http://www.tractiontime.co.uk/modules/extcal/calendar-month.php Live listings of UK Steam and Vintage Events] (Visitors may also submit to this Events Guide) * [http://www.mortonsmediagroup.com/ogevents/eventsguide.asp "Old Glory" Online Guide to UK Events] including steam rallies and fairs (dynamic list) - [http://www.oldglory.co.uk from the Old Glory magazine] ::''(Old Glory also publishes a 'Free' paper version at the start of each year listing UK Events.)'' *[http://www.steamfairs.co.uk Search for steam fairs near you (UK only)]

to --> |coordinates = {{coord|24|47|N|110|30|E|region:CN-45|display=inline,title}} <!-- Area/postal codes & others --------> |postal_code_type = <!-- enter ZIP code, Postcode, Post code, Postal code... --> |postal_code =546700 |area_code = |website = [http://www.gxmengshan.net/index/index.asp www.gxmengshan.net] ([[Chinese language|Chinese]]) |footnotes = }} '''Mengshan County''' ({{zh|s=蒙山县 |t=蒙山縣 |p=Méngshān Xiàn}}) is a [[County (People's Republic of China)|county]] under the administration of [[Wuzhou]] City in northeastern [[Guangxi]], China. Its seat is located in Mengshan Town.
==History== Battles were fought in Mengshan during the [[Taiping Rebellion|Tai Ping Rebellion]] in 1851 and 1852.
Taiping soldiers captured the walled city of Yongan({{zh|s=永安 |t=永安|p= yǒng ān}})(now Mengshan Town) from Qing forces on September 25, 1851. The remains of sections of wall, replica cannons, other artifacts are preserved and now form a tourist attraction on the northern end of Mengshan Town.
== Administrative divisions ==
Mengshan County has nine fourth-level administrative units: Six Rural [[Town of China|Towns]], One [[Townships of the People's Republic of China|Townships]] and Two [[Yao people|Yao]] [[ethnic township]]s.
{|class="wikitable" !District !Population (2000 census) !Area (km²) |- |Mengshan Town (蒙山镇 ; méng shān zhèn) || 44,077 || 82.9 |- |Xihe Town (西河镇 ; xī hé zhèn) || 32,200 || 216 |- |Xinwei Town (新圩镇 ; xīn wéi zhèn) || 23,000 || 144 |- |Wenwei Town (文圩镇 ; wén wéi zhèn) || 34,000 || 143 |- |Huangcun Town (黄村镇 ; huáng cūn zhèn) || 22,000 || 239.8 |- |Chentang Town (陈塘镇 ; chén táng zhèn) || 21,828 || 152.29 |- |Hanhao Township (汉豪乡 ; hàn háo xiāng) || 12,175 || 106.37 |- |Changping Yaozu Area (长坪瑶族乡 ; cháng píng yáo zú xiāng) || 2,889 || 131.8 |- |Xiayi Yaozu Area (夏宜瑶族乡 ; xià yí yáo zú xiāng ) || 6,011 || 117.4 |- |'''Mengshan County''' || '''198,180''' || '''1333.56''' |}
==Activities== Tianshu Canyon ({{zh|s=天书峡谷 |t=天書峽谷|p=San tiān shū xiá gǔ}}) is located 5 kilometers east of Mengshan town. Tianshu Canyon has a has impressive stone formations and natural waterfalls. [[File:Mengshan.JPG|thumb]]
Located 13 kilometers east of Mengshan Town is San Chong Historic Battle Ground ({{zh|s=三冲古战场 |t=三衝古戰場|p=San Chong Gu Zhan Chang}}) The site of a battle on April 8, 1852 during the [[Taiping Rebellion]].
In Mengshan county in 1968 during the [[Cultural Revolution]] Cannibalism occurred. 500 people were killed in a five-day period in mid-June.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://taiwanauj.nat.gov.tw/fp.asp?xItem=1441&CtNode=128 |title=Inscribing the Unspeakable|author=Alice W. Cheang |publisher=Alice W. Cheang |year=1999|accessdate=2009-02-10}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://taiwanauj.nat.gov.tw/fp.asp?xItem=1441&CtNode=128 |title=Inscribing the Unspeakable|author=John Gittings |publisher=John Gittings |year=1993|accessdate=2009-02-10}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://repositories.cdlib.org/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=1023&context=csd |title=Mass Killings in Rural China 1967-68|author=Yang Su |publisher=University of California, Irvine) |year=2003|accessdate=2009-02-10}}</ref>
Many Middle Schools were closed in Mengshan in 1968 and remained closed until 1974.
==Transportation== Mengshan does not have an airport or railway. The closest airports to Mengshan are [[Guilin Liangjiang International Airport]] and [[Wuzhou|Wuzhou Airport]]. The main road which runs North-South through Mengshan is the G321 [[China National Highway|National Highway]] ({{zh|s=国道G321|t=國道G321|p=Guódào G sān èr yāo}}). Mengshan town is 145 km by road south of Guilin, 82 km by road south of [[Yangshuo]], and 187 km by road north of Wuzhou. The G321 is a single carriageway with 2 lanes.
There are direct bus services from Mengshan town to Guilin, Wuzhou and many cities in the Guangdong Pearl River Delta including Guangzhou and Zhongshan.
==Economy== Although similar to Guilin and Yangshuo with attractive karst scenery, potential for outdoor activities, such as caving, rafting, climbing and mountain biking, Mengshan does not have any significant tourist industry or infrastructure.
Agriculture and Forestry are the main Industries in Mengshan. Rice is grown primarily for domestic consumption. Crops and fruit such as butter tea, citrus fruit, apple, chestnut, pear, persimmon, passion fruit, star anise, sugar cane and ginger are grown for sale. Silkworms are also an important source of income for many villages. Vanilla is grown in Changping [[Yao people|Yao]] Minority Village ({{zh|s=长坪瑶族乡 |t=長坪瑤族鄉|p=Cháng Píng Yáo Zú Xiāng}}) and in other parts of Mengshan.
Tea is grown in most villages for domestic use, as well as for sale. Mengshan's climate is ideal for growing tea. Coffee mainly of the [[Coffea arabica|Arabica]] variety grows well in Mengshan county in frost free areas but planting is on small scale.
Mengshan has productive vinyards, and further vinyards are being developed.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gxny.gov.cn/web/2008-10/223029.htm|title=Grape Planting to Increase|author=Agricultural Information Center of the Guangxi Zhuang Autonomous Region|publisher=Guangxi Agricultural Information Web|date=2008-10-10|accessdate=2009-02-09|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110707034034/http://www.gxny.gov.cn/web/2008-10/223029.htm|archivedate=2011-07-07|df=}}</ref> <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gx.xinhuanet.com/dtzx/mengshan/jjjs.htm |title=Mengshan's Macroeconomy|author=gx.xinhuanet.com |publisher=gx.xinhuanet.com|year=2006|accessdate=2009-02-09}}</ref>
[[Remittance]]s from rural migrant workers significantly contribute to the local economy.
==Notable people== *[[Liang Yusheng]] (1926–2009) a famous Chinese wuxia novelist who spent his early years in Wenwei Village (文圩村 ; wén wéi cūn) Mengshan. *Chen Manyuan 陳漫遠(1911–1986) a member of the Central Committee of the CCP’s Eighth Congress (1956)

{{multiple issues| {{more citations needed|date=May 2011}} {{more footnotes|date=May 2011}} }}
{{Infobox military person |name= Suzanne Marie Collins |birth_date= {{birth date|1966|6|8}} |death_date= {{death date and age|1985|7|12|1966|6|8}} |death_place= [[Millington, Tennessee]] |image= Suzanne Collins.gif |caption= |nickname= |allegiance= [[United States|United States of America]] |branch= [[United States Marine Corps]] [[File:USMC logo.svg|25px]] |serviceyears= 1984 - 1985 |rank= [[Lance Corporal#United States|Lance Corporal]] |commands= |unit=[[Naval Air Station|Naval Air Station, Memphis]] |laterwork= }} '''Suzanne Marie Collins''' was a [[United States Marine Corps|U. S. Marine Corps]] Lance Corporal who was tortured, raped and murdered by '''Sedley Alley''' in 1985. At the time of her murder she was stationed at [[Naval Air Station Memphis]] in [[Millington, Tennessee]]. Collins was a student undergoing training at the base, and was scheduled to graduate from avionics training on the day of her murder. She is buried in [[Arlington National Cemetery]].
Suzanne Collins was the daughter of Jack and Trudy Collins. She graduated from [[Robert E. Lee High School (Fairfax County, Virginia)|Robert E. Lee High School]] in [[Springfield, Virginia]].
==Abduction and murder== Sedley Alley (August 16, 1955 - June 28, 2006), a civilian married to an enlisted member of the military, abducted Collins late in the evening of July 11, 1985 while she was jogging on the base. He took her to nearby Edmund Orgill Park. Once there he beat her multiple times, fracturing her skull, before repeatedly shoving a tree limb up her vagina with enough force to penetrate her abdomen and tear one of her lungs. The autopsy would state that Collins died from blunt force trauma to the head and internal hemorrhaging from the tree limb.<ref name="Douglas1997" /> He then ditched the body and fled the scene.
Two Marines jogging near where Collins was abducted heard her scream and ran toward the sound. However, as they reached the scene, they saw Alley's car leaving the area. They reported to base security and accompanied officers on a tour of the base, looking for the car. Unsuccessful, they returned to their [[barracks]], but soon the Marines were called back to the security office. There they identified Alley's car, which had been stopped by officers. Alley and his wife gave statements to the base security personnel accounting for their whereabouts. The security personnel were satisfied with Alley's story, and Alley and his wife returned to their on-base housing. The two Marine witnesses returned to the security office shortly after Alley and his wife departed. The Marines disputed the couple's version of events, citing that the loud, distinct sounds made by the [[muffler]] on Alley's car matched those sounds they had heard prior to and during Collins' abduction. The security personnel indicated that since no one had yet been reported missing, there was nothing more that could be done. The Marines were thanked for their assistance and told to return to their barracks.<ref name="Douglas1997">Douglas, John E. (1997). Journey Into Darkness. New York: Lisa Drew Book/Schribner. {{ISBN|0684833042}}.</ref>
Collins' body was discovered the next morning by sheriff's deputies, after her roommate reported her missing. When word got to the base of the murder, Alley was immediately arrested by [[military police]]. He voluntarily gave a statement to the police, admitting to having killed Collins but giving a substantially false account of the circumstances of the killing. He claimed that his wife Lynne went to a [[Tupperware party]] which had angered him. He drank two six-packs of beer and a bottle of wine. He told authorities that he had gone out for more liquor when his car accidentally hit Collins as she jogged near the air base. He also claimed he accidentally killed the young woman when she fell on a [[screwdriver]] he was holding as he was trying to help her. However, an [[autopsy]] revealed that her skull had been fractured with repeated beatings, there were no screwdriver wounds, and no wounds consistent with being hit by a car.<ref name="Douglas1997" />
==Trial and execution of Alley== In spite of his attempt to convince a jury that he had [[multiple personality disorder]], Alley was convicted on March 18, 1987 of murder in the first degree and on May 17, 1987, was sentenced to death. He was also convicted of aggravated kidnapping and aggravated rape, for which he received consecutive forty-year sentences.<ref name="Douglas1997" /> He was scheduled to die by electrocution May 2, 1990, but was reprieved indefinitely by the state Court of Criminal Appeals.
A Shelby County judge denied Alley's initial request for state-funded DNA testing of 11 samples of physical evidence, saying he hadn't shown "reasonable probability" that he wouldn't have been prosecuted or convicted if the tests were in his favor.<ref>Tennessee, State of. "RESPONSE OF THE STATE TO PETITIONER'S PETITION FOR DNA TESTING PURSUANT TO T.C.A. §40-30-301 ET SEQ.". Tennessee Administrative Office of the Courts. Tennessee State Courts. Retrieved 07/05/2013.</ref>
After numerous appeals, Alley was executed by [[lethal injection]] at the [[Riverbend Maximum Security Institution]] in Nashville, Tennessee, on the morning of June 28, 2006; he was pronounced dead at 2:12 a.m.<ref name="Wood">Wood, E. Thomas. "Sedley Alley put to death at Riverbend Prison". Nashville Post. SouthComm Inc. Retrieved 07/05/2013.</ref> The length of Alley's appeals process caused Collins' family to successfully work for limitations on groundless [[habeas corpus]] appeals. The amount of time between the murder and Alley's execution (20 years, 11 months, 14 days) was actually longer than Suzanne Collins had been alive (19 years, one month, four days old) when she was killed.
The books ''Journey Into Darkness '' and ''Law & Disorder'' by [[John E. Douglas]] dedicate three chapters to the life and murder of Suzanne Collins and to the advocacy work of her parents following the murder.<ref name="Douglas1997" />
==Advocacy of Jack and Trudy Collins== After the murder, the Collinses dealt with their [[grief]] in part by joining a Fairfax County support group for surviving members of homicide victims led by Carroll Ellis and Sandra Witt.<ref>Douglas, John E. (1997). Journey Into Darkness. New York: Lisa Drew Book/Schribner. pp. 261–262. {{ISBN|0684833042}}.</ref> Due to involvement with the group, the Collinses got more involved in attending the hearings and criminal proceedings of the killers of their loved ones. With the appeals of Alley stretching into years,<ref name="Wood" /> the Collinses became frustrated with the long [[habeas corpus]] appeals and continuing delay of Alley's sentence. Both Collinses then became deeply involved with activism and reform work.
In March 1991, J. Collins addressed delegates at the Crime Summit in [[Washington, D.C.]], convened by then [[Attorney general|Attorney General]] [[Richard Thornburgh]].<ref>Thornburgh, Richard. "CLOSING REMARKS of • ATTORNEY GENERAL RICHARD THORNBURGH". United States Department of Justice. United States Dept of Justice. Retrieved 07/06/2013.</ref> Collins's statement was about the lack of finality with criminal convictions and pressing for reform. In the early 1990s, both Collinses became Eastern Regional Directors of Citizens for Law and Order, based in [[Oakland, California]].<ref>Douglas, John E. (1997). Journey Into Darkness. New York: Lisa Drew Book/Schribner. p. 268. {{ISBN|0684833042}}</ref> J. Collins continued with opportunities presented to the couple and worked with Executive Director Lee Chancellor of the Judicial Reform Foundation to create a pamphlet on habeas corpus abuses and history of the [[judicial process]].<ref>Douglas, John E. (1997). Journey Into Darkness. New York: Lisa Drew Book/Schribner. p. 269. {{ISBN|0684833042}}.</ref> On May 7, 1991, J. Collins testified before Congress on habeas corpus reform and the endless appeals that Alley was requesting. T. Collins was in attendance in support of her husband.<ref>Douglas, John E. (1997). Journey Into Darkness. New York: Lisa Drew Book/Schribner. p. 270. {{ISBN|0684833042}}.</ref>
The Collinses have also established a scholarship named the Suzanne Marie Collins Perpetual Scholarship, first awarded in 1996.<ref>"Spotlight on Donors: Financial Aid". American Foreign Service Association. American Foreign Service Association. Retrieved 07/06/2013.</ref>
